description: On January 8, 2004, the keys to the new Foreign Ministry conference room, entirely renovated by China, were handed over to the DRC. The Chinese Embassy committed 724,880.75 USD for the project and disbursed 724,923.04 USD for the renovations, which were completed between 2003 and 2004.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAP00020040110e01a0002t&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pga.ministereduplan.cd, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: On January 22, 2003, Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan announced that China would provide the Congo an aid package worth 20 million CNY for economic cooperation. The sector of the agreement is not clear. The terms of the agreement were untied allowing politics to be avoided. On January 7, 2004, China granted the 20 million CNY to the DRC. This was during a meeting in which the minister of foreign affairs and international cooperation signed two technical and economic cooperation agreements and presented the keys to the Foreign Ministry's conference room, which was renovated by Chinese donations.

description: China committed 13,289,484.98 USD to the Democratic Republic of Congo between 2001 and 2004. The purpose of the donation is unclear, although the DRC's Aid Management Platform indicated that the donation was allocated for projects in multiple sectors. In total, 13,289,542.38 USD was disbursed. In 2002, 6,040,745.69 USD was disbursed. In 2003, 4,832,401.95 USD was disbursed, and in 2004, 2,416,337.34 USD was disbursed.
sources: http://pga.ministereduplan.cd, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: On August 8th, 2000, Xinhua and Radio-Television Nationale Congolaise (RTNC) signed an information supply agreement. RTNC was represented by Managing Director Jose Kazangua, and Xinhua was represented by Yu Chang, managing director of Xinhua's branch in the DRC. The contract offered RTNC the choice of receiving information from Xinhua in both French and Chinese, and put a small satellite receiver unit and diskette at the disposal of the RTNC as practical support. The exact start and end dates of this project are yet unknown.

description: In 2000, China provided the DRC food aid. China provided 1600 tonnes of rice and 950 tonnes of corn. According to the DRC's Aid Management Platform, China committed 603921.99 USD for humanitarian aid, but 604073.02 USD was disbursed.
sources: http://pga.ministereduplan.cd, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: In 2000, ZTE and the DRCongolese Office of Post Telecommunications (OCPT) signed a joint venture agreement and formed China-Congo Telecom (CCT). ZTE holds a 51% share of this joint venture, and has agreed to help run the project for 30 years. The Export-Import Bank of China then agreed to provide 80 million CNY in preferential loans for CCT telecommunications projects in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Most of this loan has been spent on purchasing equipment from ZTE. At the time of signing, the total required investment was estimated at 164 million CNY. On October 20, 2011 France Telecom-Orange announced they had purchased 100% of CCT from ZTE and the DRCongolese government for a total of 17 million USD, with 10 million USD going to ZTE and 7 million USD going to the government. According to the DRC's Aid Management Platform records, China committed 1,069,417.79 USD to the project and disbursed 9,664,647.96 USD (approximately 80000000 CNY) (AMP ID #1120091254534). Another entry (AMP ID #112009761000) also mentions the creation of CCT with slightly different commitment and disbursement amounts (9,664,765.67 USD and 9,665,626.249 USD, respectively).

description: The Chinese government awards scholarships to students from the DRC on an annual basis since 1985. Each scholarship is good for five years of study in China. From 2000 to 2008, over 82 scholarships were awarded to the Congolese. The financial amount for these projects is yet unknown. The scholarships per year are as follow: 1985-2003: 5-8;2004-2006: 11;2007: 23;2008: 32;
sources: http://www.ccs.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2010/03/ENGLISH-Evaluating-Chinas-FOCAC-commitments-to-Africa-2010.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

description: China has been sending medial teams to Democratic Republic of Congo every two years since 1973. China stopped sending medical teams in 1997 due to internal turmoil. The medical teams resumed in 2008, and Hebei Province is responsible for sending the teams. The 16th medical team of 17 members arrived in DRC in May 2014.
sources: http://www.hebwst.gov.cn:9999/index.do?id=55178&templet=con_news&cid=122, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.nhfpc.gov.cn/yjb/fkgzgzdt/201411/c2f1b5544f184c4e99ce1981551d8a52.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://news.xinhuanet.com/2015-03/21/c_1114715604.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://cd.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201408/20140800692017.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: Summary: In response to the Ebola virus, Xi Jinping announced that China was donating 200 million yuan to West African countries to battle the virus. This included 5 million RMB worth of materials for Ghana, Mali, Benin, Guinea Bissau and the Democratic Republic of Congo each. Sep 26, 2014 (Forum on China-Africa Cooperation/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- Chinese President Xi Jinping announced on 18th September a new aid package of 200 million yuan (about $33 million) for West African countries to help combat the deadly Ebola virus. Meanwhile, new batches of Chinese medical experts will be sent to Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea. Under the aid package, each country of Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea will be provided with $1 million cash as well as $2 million worth food and materials for disease prevention, control and treatment. Nigeria will be offered $1.6 million materials, and materials worth $0.8 million will be offered to each country of Mali, Ghana, Benin, Guinea Bissau, Ivory Coast and Democratic Republic of Congo. In addition, China will donate mobile laboratories to Sierra Leone, and help Sierra Leone build fixed laboratories with supporting screening and security equipments. Moreover, China will also provide the World Health Organization and the African Union each with $2 million in cash in a bid to support international and regional organizations concerned to play a leading and coordinating role in fighting the epidemic. In April and August, China sent 2 batches of relief goods worth 33 million RMB yuan (about $5.4 million) and medical experts to Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea-Bissau. Currently there is a total of 174 Chinese medical workers in the three seriously Ebola-affected countries for the prevention and containment of the epidemic. 中国医疗物资助刚果（金）防控埃博拉 2014年10月30日 09:22:07 来源： 新华网 新华网金沙萨１０月２９日电（记者王博　刘锴）中国驻刚果（金）大使馆２９日代表中国政府向刚方政府捐赠一批医疗援助物资，以协助刚果（金）防控埃博拉疫情。 这批医疗援助物资包括１.７万套防护服、防护镜等防护装备，以及消毒手套、尸体袋等善后物资，当天运抵刚果（金）首都金沙萨。 中国驻刚果（金）大使馆代办陈志宏在捐赠仪式上说，埃博拉病毒对所有国家公共卫生系统都构成威胁。作为好兄弟和好伙伴，在困难时刻，中国人总会与非洲兄弟姐妹并肩。他同时赞赏刚果（金）政府为防控埃博拉疫情所做努力。 刚果（金）卫生部负责人维维娜·蒙巴称赞中方援助及时高效，患难才能见真情。 刚果（金）西北部赤道省今年７月底出现埃博拉疫情，共确诊３８例埃博拉感染病例，确诊病例中有２１人死亡、１７人已恢复健康。此次疫情共造成４９人死亡，除２１例确诊病例死亡外，还包括２８例高度疑似病例。截至本月２９日，刚果（金）已连续２５天未出现新增病例，疫情有望于１１月１５日解除。 (On behalf of the Chinese government, the Chinese Embassy in Democratic Republic of Congo donated to the local government medical materials to help with fighting the Ebola virus on Oct 29.) 中国政府援刚果（金）埃博拉防控救治物资换文在金沙萨签署 文章来源：驻刚果（金）使馆经商参处　　 2014-09-29 21:45 9月26日，驻刚果（金）大使王英武和刚外交部负责国际与地区合作的副部长马格本古在刚外交部举行仪式，代表各自政府签署援刚埃博拉防控救治物资的换文。使馆政务、经济外交官和刚外交部高级官员出席仪式。 王大使指出，当前非洲埃博拉疫情加剧蔓延，已成为国际社会面临的共同挑战。中国高度关注非洲国家埃博拉疫情，在第一时间向有关国家提供了紧急援助，并派遣医护人员帮助非洲国家抗击埃博拉。9月18日，习近平主席宣布了新一轮总额为2亿元人民币的一揽子援助计划，显示了中国的国际责任和中非患难真情。为协助刚政府和人民抗击疫情，中国政府已向刚派出三名医疗专家。此次又决定向刚援助一批防护救治物资，相信在各方支持和帮助下，刚政府和人民一定能取得抗击埃博拉的最后胜利。 马格本古副外长说，中非人民相互怀有长期深厚的兄弟情谊。刚赤道省博恩代县出现疫情后，刚政府向国际社会发出了援助请求，中国是第一个积极回应并提供切实帮助的国家。中国的实际行动予刚方大力支持，将为刚抗击疫情发挥重要作用。刚政府和人民将对中国政府和人民心怀感激。 刚多家主流媒体对仪式进行了报道。（孙长林） (Wang Yingwu, the Chinese Ambassador in the Democratic Republic of Congo, signed the medial equipment donation agreement with the vice minister of foreign affairs of the Democratic Republic of Congo on Sept 26.) 中国政府为刚果（金）等国抗击埃博拉疫情提供援助 2014/09/23 　　9月18日，中国国家主席习近平在访问印度期间宣布，中国政府将再次向非洲国家抗击埃博拉疫情提供援助。 　　习近平指出，当前西非埃博拉疫情加剧蔓延，给国际社会带来严峻挑战。为支持西非等疫区国家抗击埃博拉疫情，帮助疫区周边国家加强防疫能力建设，支持有关国际地区组织在抗疫斗争中继续发挥领导和协调作用，中国政府决定向上述国家和组织提供金额为2亿元人民币的现汇、粮食和物资援助。其中大部分将提供给有关国家，同时，中方还向世界卫生组织和非盟各提供200万美元现汇援助。中方的行动充分体现了中国与非洲国家患难之交的真挚情谊，得到了疫区国家和联合国以及世卫组织的高度肯定。 　　刚果（金）是此次援助对象国之一。自今年8月在刚赤道省出现埃博拉确诊病例以来，刚政府和人民为抗击疫情做出了不懈努力。为帮助刚方抗击疫情，中国政府已向刚派遣3名医疗专家，并决定向刚政府援助一批价值500万元人民币的防护救治物资。 　　今年4月和8月，中方先后向西非疫区国家提供了两批总额为3400万元人民币的援助。中方还派遣了100余名医疗专家赴有关国家协助防疫工作，并要求驻疫区国家医疗队坚持工作。目前，共有174名中国医务人员在疫区工作。 (Chinese President, Xi Jinping, announce during his visit in India that China will provide Congo(K) 5 million RMB worth of aid materials to help combat Ebola.) 驻刚果（金）大使王英武与刚方签署援刚埃博拉防控救治物资的换文 2014/09/27 　　马格本古副外长说，中非人民相互怀有长期深厚的兄弟情谊。刚赤道省博恩代县出现疫情后，刚政府向国际社会发出了援助请求，中国是第一个积极回应并提供切实帮助的国家。中国的实际行动予刚方大力支持，将为刚抗击疫情发挥重要作用。刚政府和人民将对中国政府和人民心怀感激。 　　刚多家主流媒体对仪式进行了报道。 (Wang Yingwu, the Chinese Ambassador in the Democratic Republic of Congo, signed the medial equipment donation agreement of 5,000,000RMB worth with the vice minister of foreign affairs of the Democratic Republic of Congo on Sept 26. ) 中国援助刚果（金）应对埃博拉防护物资交接仪式在金沙萨举行 2014/10/31 　　为帮助非洲国家应对埃博拉疫情，中国政府启动第三轮物资援助，向包括刚果（金）在内的非洲十国提供总价值5500万元人民币的防护物资。 　　10月29日16时，满载着援非抗埃博拉防护物资的中国政府包机抵达金沙萨恩吉利国际机场。我驻刚使馆与刚卫生部在机场举行物资交接仪式。使馆临时代办陈志宏、经商参赞周芒胜、刚代理卫生部长（司法部长）蒙巴、人权副部长萨基娜、卫生部及外交部高级官员、世卫组织驻刚代表，以及部分受援国驻刚使节出席。 　　陈代办与蒙巴部长分别代表两国政府签署物资交接证书，并发表讲话。 　　陈代办全面介绍了自西非埃博拉疫情爆发以来，中国政府对疫区及周边国家、世卫组织、非盟等的援助情况，并表示，埃博拉已成为世界各国公共卫生的共同威胁，作为非洲国家和人民的好兄弟、好朋友、好伙伴，中国政府和人民始终与非洲兄弟站在一起，共克时艰。近日，习近平主席宣布中国政府将再向西非疫区和有关国际组织提供总价值5亿元人民币的急需物资和现汇援助，并将派出更多中国防疫专家和医护人员，帮助疫区国家抗击埃博拉疫情。陈代办说，很高兴看到在国际社会与疫区国家的共同努力下，埃博拉疫情在一些国家得到了有效抑制。刚方不但在防控本国疫情方面取得成绩，还派专家赴西非参与抗击埃博拉行动，中方对此表示钦佩和赞赏。祝愿刚能早日结束疫情，相信在国际社会的共同努力下，抗击埃博拉在不久的将来必将取得全面胜利。 　　蒙巴部长表示，因卫生部长卡邦格出差，她代表刚政府参加本次交接仪式，并向中国政府和人民表示感谢。如没有新增确诊病例，刚有望于十几天后宣布疫情结束。刚抗击埃博拉疫情处于关键时期，应更加提高警惕，保持谨慎。中国的援助将极大提升刚防控埃博拉等各类恶性传染病的能力，并再次体现刚中两国和两国人民间的真挚友情和友好合作关系。 　　仪式结束后，陈代办接受了中国中央电视台和当地媒体的采访。刚国家电视台、《潜力报》、《精英论坛报》等主流媒体对物资交接仪式进行了报道。 (Handover ceremony of Chinese aid materials took place in Kinshasa airport.) 中国政府援刚果（金）埃博拉防控救治物资换文在金沙萨签署 9月26日，驻刚果（金）大使王英武和刚外交部负责国际与地区合作的副部长马格本古在刚外交部举行仪式，代表各自政府签署援刚埃博拉防控救治物资的换文。使馆政务、经济外交官和刚外交部高级官员出席仪式。 王大使指出，当前非洲埃博拉疫情加剧蔓延，已成为国际社会面临的共同挑战。中国高度关注非洲国家埃博拉疫情，在第一时间向有关国家提供了紧急援助，并派遣医护人员帮助非洲国家抗击埃博拉。9月18日，习近平主席宣布了新一轮总额为2亿元人民币的一揽子援助计划，显示了中国的国际责任和中非患难真情。为协助刚政府和人民抗击疫情，中国政府已向刚派出三名医疗专家。此次又决定向刚援助一批防护救治物资，相信在各方支持和帮助下，刚政府和人民一定能取得抗击埃博拉的最后胜利。 马格本古副外长说，中非人民相互怀有长期深厚的兄弟情谊。刚赤道省博恩代县出现疫情后，刚政府向国际社会发出了援助请求，中国是第一个积极回应并提供切实帮助的国家。中国的实际行动予刚方大力支持，将为刚抗击疫情发挥重要作用。刚政府和人民将对中国政府和人民心怀感激。 刚多家主流媒体对仪式进行了报道。（孙长林） (The exchange of notes regarding China's medical material donation to Congo(K) to combat Ebola was signed by Wang Yingwu, Chinese Ambassador to Congo(K), and Dismas Magbengu Swana Emin, the vice Minister of International and Regional Cooperation of the Embassy of Congo(K), on Sept. 26, 2014.) 援刚果（金）防控埃博拉疫情救治物资交接仪式在金沙萨国际机场隆重举行 29日下午4时15分，中国政府向刚果（金）、马里、加纳、贝宁、几内亚比绍、科特迪瓦等六国运送应对埃博拉疫情防护救治物资的飞机降落在金沙萨恩吉利国际机场。刚果（金）是该专机物资运抵的首站。 下午5点左右，中国政府援刚果（金）抗击埃博拉疫情救治物资交接仪式在金沙萨恩吉利国际机场隆重举行。中国驻刚果（金）大使馆临时代办陈志宏、刚果（金）司法与人权部长蒙巴（代卫生部长出席）、卫生部办公厅主任、外交合作部亚美司司长以及世界卫生组织驻刚果（金）代表和马里、加纳、科特迪瓦、贝宁等国驻刚使馆代表等约100多人出席了仪式。 陈志宏代办在飞机旁将防护服等救治物资向蒙巴部长做了象征性的交接。随后，陈志宏代办和蒙巴部长分别代表各自政府签署了交接证书。 陈代办说，中国政府高度关注非洲国家埃博拉疫情，在第一时间向有关国家提供了紧急援助，并派遣医护人员帮助非洲国家抗击埃博拉。9月18日，习近平主席宣布了第三轮总额为2亿元人民币的一揽子援助计划；10月24日，习近平主席宣布向非洲有关国家抗击埃博拉疫情提供第四轮总价值为5亿元人民币的紧急援助，显示了中国的国际责任和中非患难真情。为协助刚政府和人民抗击疫情，中国政府已向刚派出三名医疗专家。此次向刚援助的价值500万元人民币的防护救治物资，是落实上述第三轮一揽子援助计划的具体行动之一，相信在各方支持和帮助下，刚政府和人民一定能取得抗击埃博拉的最后胜利。 蒙巴部长说，刚中两国人民相互怀有长期深厚的兄弟情谊。刚赤道省博恩代县出现埃博拉疫情后，刚政府向国际社会发出了援助请求，中国是第一个积极回应并提供切实帮助的国家。中国的实际行动予刚方大力支持，刚政府将尽快把该批援助物资分发到相关部门，使其为刚抗击疫情发挥重要作用。蒙巴部长请陈代办转达刚政府和人民对中国政府和人民及时提供无私援助的真诚谢意！ 刚多家主流媒体及中央电视台驻刚记者站对仪式进行了报道。 (The handover ceremony of Chinese donation to Congo(K) for combating Ebola was held in Kinshasa Airport. This is one of the actions taken in the third round of China's aid for Congo(K) to combat Ebola.)

description: SUMMARY: On July 13, 2003, China donated agricultural equipment and computers for Ecuadorian provincial governments. In total, the items are valued around $2.5 million. The donation included 120 tractors, 215 different computer components, 23 cars and a bus. Before 2003, China had extended 8 credit lines without interest and 17 grants that have financed 39 projects for economic and technical cooperation. In 2002, economic ties amounted o 240 million USD. STAFF_NOTE: Specific locations/beneficiaries of equipment transfer is unknown.

description: SUMMARY: On August 31, 2006, the Red Cross Society of China provided money and equipment as part of an international response to a volcanic eruption in Ecuador on August 16, 2006. The foreign aid included sanitary and medical equipment, tents, coats, foods and water purification devices. Cotopaxi, Chimborazo and Pastaza were the most affected provinces. The total donations were valued at $1.4 million but it is unclear to what extent China contributed to this total amount. As of October 2006, relief materials had been distributed and the Chinese Embassador Yuquín Liu had recently visited the affected areas to boost moral and thank Red Cross volunteers.

description: SUMMARY: In 2009, China Development Bank agreed to grant the State Bank of Ecuador an interest free loan and credit line worth US$30 million for several uses. The money will be used for medical supplies ($4.3 million), completing the Quitumbe Bus Terminal ($18 million) in Quito, and a $7.3 million credit line to boost agricultural trade and production. The terminal has since been completed. This project is linked to #35866 and #35851 _________________________________________ China, Ecuador sign US$25 mln agreements 167 words 16 February 2009 China Knowledge Press CHIKNO English Copyright 2009 China Knowledge Online Pte Ltd. All rights Reserved. Feb. 16, 2009 (China Knowledge) - China signed four cooperation agreements totaling US$25 million with Ecuador last Friday to strengthen ties and deepen mutual trust, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. The mutually beneficial agreements were signed by visiting Chinese Vice Premier Hui Liangyu and Ecuadorian Vice President Lenin Moreno. China agreed to offer a credit line of RMB 50 million (about US$7.3 million) to boost trade in agricultural products and investment in Ecuador's agricultural sector. China will also grant credit of US $18 million for completion of the Ground Terminal Quitumbe, situated in the south of Quito, according to an arrangement between the State Bank of Ecuador and the China Development Bank. Ecuador will soon set up trade offices in the Chinese cities of Shanghai and Guangzhou to facilitate trade with China, said Moreno. The trade volume between the two countries hit a record high of US$2.38 billion last year, double that in 2007. China Knowledge Online Pte Ltd Document CHIKNO0020090216e52g0002u

description: SUMMARY: In 2009, China Development Bank agreed to grant the State Bank of Ecuador an interest free loan and credit line worth US$30 million for several uses. The money will be used for medical supplies ($4.3 million), completing the Quitumbe Bus Terminal ($18 million) in Quito, and a $7.3 million credit line to boost agricultural trade and production. The terminal has since been completed. This project is linked to #35866 and #35867 _________________________________________ China dará a Ecuador crédito sin intereses por 20 millones de dólares 204 words 13 February 2009 03:10 PM Agence France Presse AFPES Spanish Copyright Agence France-Presse, 2009 All reproduction and presentation rights reserved. China otorgará a Ecuador un crédito sin intereses por 20 millones de dólares, según un acuerdo suscrito este viernes durante la visita a Quito de una delegación encabezada por viceprimer ministro chino, Hui Liangyu, informó la cancillería ecuatoriana. El compromiso está incluido en una serie de instrumentos adoptados por los dos países que prevén, además, una donación por 4,3 millones de dólares, equipos médicos y un acuerdo de financiación por 18 millones de dólares para viales en Quito, según la Cancillería. Hui Liangyu y el vicecanciller chino Song Tao se reunieron con el canciller ecuatoriano, Fander Falconí, para analizar la agenda bilateral. También 'analizaron los efectos de la crisis financiera mundial y cuáles serían los mecanismos pertinentes para afrontarla', agregó Quito. Las relaciones entre los dos países se han intensificado a raíz de la visita oficial que realizó Correa en noviembre de 2007. La balanza comercial con Asia -continente dentro del cual China es el principal mercado- es deficitaria para Ecuador. En 2008 las exportaciones ecuatorianas llegaron a 625 millones de dólares y las importaciones a 4.278 millones (récords desde 2001). vel/rs Ecuador-China-diplomacia Ecuador-China-diplomacia Agence France-Presse Document AFPES00020090213e52d00490

description: SUMMARY: China and Ecuador signed 3 bilateral agreements in 2009. The first was a donation of $1.4 million (#35844). The second is a $3 million, no interest for ten years (#35845) line of credit, and the third is a $438 million line of credit to buy four Chinese military planes for Ecuador's air force (#35846). The second and third are both lines of credit but with varying terms. There aren't any reports detailing the completion of these agreements.

description: At the end of 2009, talks began between Ecuador and China for a 1 billion USD oil-for-loan agreement. The loan was signed in 2010 with China Development Bank with a fixed interest rate of 6% per year for a four-year term and an additional six-month grace period. STAFF NOTES: This is a commodity-backed or resource-backed loan. One Chinese source has been added, mentioning the 2010 project but focusing more on the 2013 loan.

description: SUMMARY: On November 11, 2011 the Confucius Institute at the San Francisco University of Quito held its first anniversary celebration in Quito. This location was the first Confucius Institute in Ecuador. Nearly 800 students have enrolled to learn Chinese. STAFF_NOTE: Specific financial details unknown.

description: China has decided to assist Ecuador in establishing an integrated security service called ECU 911 to protect and maintain social order in the country. InSight Crime, a non-profit investigative journalism website specializing in organized crime in Latin America and the Caribbean, reported two years ago (2012) that Ecuador would receive a loan of US$240 million from China to set up the project. Two of the 16 points constructed throughout the entire nation were in operation already by the end of 2012. Others were activated by the end of 2013 according to the website.

description: SUMMARY: In 2013, China donated a mobile field hospital to the Ecuadoran armed forces. The hospital will be used for medical emergencies and rescue operations during natural disasters. Its value is not reported. The hand-over ceremony took place in the city of Loja. __________________________________________ China donates mobile hospital to Ecuador WuDingBao 158 words 19 July 2013 03:50 PM Xinhua News Agency XNEWS English Copyright 2013. Xinhua News Agency. All rights reserved. QUITO, July 19 (Xinhua) -- China Friday donated a mobile army surgical hospital to the Ecuadoran armed forces to aid in medical emergencies and rescue operations during natural disasters. China's Ambassador to Ecuador Wang Shixiong presided over the hand-over, which took place Friday at a military brigade in Ecuador's southern city of Loja, as part of a military-assistance accord signed in May 2012 between the countries' respective ministers of defense. The unit, a compact mobile hospital equipped for surgery, is fitted with x-ray and ultrasound machines, sterilization gear, pharmaceuticals and more. It is 'high-tech and highly mobile' and 'can be stationed on a mountain top in the jungle, desert or any other place.' Ambassador Wang said on the occasion that the unit 'fulfills all of Ecuador's technical requirements and its donation marks the deep friendship between the two nations and the two armed forces.' 01 Xinhua News Agency Document XNEWS00020130719e97j00a6p -------- Translation: July 19, in the capital city Loja Ecuador Loja Province, China sent a cross field training experts to explain the method of operation oxygen production truck to Eritrea staff. The same day, China's assistance to Ecuador field hospital equipment handover ceremony was held in the city of Loja. 7月19日，在厄瓜多尔洛哈省首府洛哈市，中方派遣的交装培训专家向厄方人员讲解制氧车的操作方法。当天，中国援助厄瓜多尔野战医院装备交接仪式在洛哈市举行。

description: Ecuador signed an agreement with the Chinese FiberHome Technologies Group to establish new operations in Ecuador’s Manabí Province. The foreign ministry said that a pilot project, estimated to cost some $20 million, will be co-financed in part with resources from the company and by the Chinese government with concessional funding.The factory broke ground in 2014. STAFF_NOTE: It is unclear how much financing the Chinese government is providing for this project.

description: Sinohydro is constructing the 1500MW Coca-Codo Sinclair hydroelectric dam in Ecuador financed mainly by the China Exim Bank and partially by the Ecuadorian government. The total cost of the project is $2 billion, and the Exim bank is covering 85% with a $1,682,745,000 loan payable in 15 years at a 6.9% interest rate. The project is currently under construction by Sinohydro and expected to be completed in 2016.

description: China ExIm bank financed 621.7 million USD of the 670 million USD project to build he Sopladora Hydropower Station, which is currently being constructed. Planning began in 2006, but the loan agreement was signed in 2010. China Gezhouba Group Corporation was the sole contractor. The construction started on April 26, 2011 with a contract period of four years.

description: SUMMARY: Ecuador signed a US$ 2b loan deal with China Development Bank at 6.9% interest, 8 year maturity, and a 2 or 3 year grace period. The $2 billion will have two function: $1.4 billion is up to Ecuador's discretion while $600 million is tied to developing energy related infrastructure. The loan has not reached maturity. This loan was soon signed after a renewed $1 billion prepayment plan between PetroChina and PetroEcuador detailed in Project #36358. _______________________________________________________ 5th UPDATE: Ecuador Negotiates $2 Billion Loan With China 562 words 14 June 2011 10:42 PM Dow Jones Global FX & Fixed Income News CM English © 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. (Updates throughout with Finance Minister comments and details about the loan.) By Mercedes Alvaro Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES QUITO (Dow Jones)--Ecuador is negotiating a $2 billion loan with China to finance several projects, Finance Minister Patricio Rivera told reporters in Guayaquil late Tuesday. Andes, Ecuador's state news agency, said the interest rate on the eight-year loan will be 6.9%, and it will have a two- or three-year grace period. The loan underscores the Asian giant's growing role as Ecuador's leading lender since the South American country defaulted on $3.2 billion of government bonds in 2008, effectively losing access to overseas capital markets. Ecuador has also opened the door for China to invest in its considerable oil and mineral resources, with China becoming the largest foreign investor in the resource-rich South American nation. At the same time, the leftist administration of President Rafael Correa has turned its back on the Washington D.C.-based International Monetary Fund and World Bank. Financing from other multilateral lenders such as the Andean Development Corporation and the Inter-American Development Bank usually is tied to specific projects. Economists say Correa's government needs the China-sourced liquidity to maintain its high public expenditure. A source close to the negotiations between the two countries told Dow Jones Newswires that the loan will have two tranches, 'one of these could be for $1 billion or $1.4 billion and (won't be tied to specific projects), and the remainder will be for financing specific projects agreed by both sides.' People familiar with the situation told Dow Jones Newswires earlier in the day that Ecuador and China had agreed on a $1 billion loan for the Andean country. The source also said 'it could be possible to get another $1 billion from China.' 'The negotiations for the new loan have been completed. We are in the final stage before signing the loan contract,' said one of the people, who asked not to be named. Meanwhile, a top government official said a team from Ecuador led by officials from the Finance Ministry will travel to China next week to work out some of the details on the loan's conditions. Rivera also said Tuesday that Ecuador has secured a $123 million loan from Russia to finance part of the construction of Toachi-Pilaton hydroelectric power plant. He said the country is negotiating several credit lines with different countries, such as China, Russia and Brazil. In February, Ecuador received a $1 billion pre-payment from China's state-owned PetroChina Co. after the two sides agreed to renew an agreement on the supply of Ecuadorean crude oil for two years, starting in August. In July 2009, state-run Petroecuador and PetroChina signed a similar agreement for Petroecuador to sell Oriente and Napo crude to PetroChina. In August of that year, the Andean country received an advance payment of $1 billion, at an interest rate of 7.25%. Last year, Ecuador's government signed a loan agreement for $1 billion with the China Development Bank Corp., with a fixed interest rate of 6% per year for a four-year term and an additional six-month grace period. -By Mercedes Alvaro, Dow Jones Newswires; 5939-9728-653; mercedes.alvaro@dowjones.com [ 06-14-11 2242ET ] Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Document CM00000020110615e76f0000k WSJ UPDATE: Ecuador Looks To China For $2 Billion Loan Mercedes Alvaro By Mercedes Alvaro Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL 509 words 14 June 2011 11:48 PM Dow Jones International News DJI English (c) 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. QUITO, Ecuador (Dow Jones)--Ecuador is negotiating a $2 billion loan with China to finance several projects, Finance Minister Patricio Rivera said late Tuesday, according to the Andean nation's state news agency, Andes. The loan underscores the Asian giant's growing role as Ecuador's leading lender since the South American country defaulted on $3.2 billion of government bonds in 2008, effectively losing access to overseas capital markets. Ecuador has also opened the door for China to invest in its considerable oil and mineral resources, with China becoming the largest foreign investor in the resource-rich South American nation. At the same time, the leftist administration of President Rafael Correa has turned its back on the Washington D.C.-based International Monetary Fund and World Bank. Financing from other multilateral lenders such as the Andean Development Corporation and the Inter-American Development Bank usually is tied to specific projects. Economists say Mr. Correa's government needs the China-sourced liquidity to maintain its high public expenditure. Andes reported that the interest rate on the eight-year loan will be 6.9%, and it will have a two- or three-year grace period. A person close to the negotiations between the two countries told Dow Jones Newswires that the loan will have two tranches, 'one of these could be for $1 billion or $1.4 billion and (won't be tied to specific projects), and the remainder will be for financing specific projects agreed by both sides.' 'The negotiations for the new loan have been completed. We are in the final stage before signing the loan contract,' said one person close to the negotiations. An Ecuadorian government official said a Finance Ministry team will travel next week to China, which has also been sharply increasing its loans and investment activities in Venezuela, Brazil and Argentina, to work out some of the details on the loan's conditions. Mr. Rivera also said Ecuador has secured a $123 million loan from Russia to finance part of the construction of the Toachi-Pilaton hydroelectric power plant. He said the country is negotiating several credit lines with other countries, too, including Brazil. In February, Ecuador received a $1 billion pre-payment from China's state-owned PetroChina Co. after the two sides agreed to renew an agreement on the supply of Ecuadorean crude oil for two years, starting in August. In July 2009, state-run Petroecuador and PetroChina signed a similar agreement for Petroecuador to sell Oriente and Napo crude to PetroChina. In August of that year, the Andean country received an advance payment of $1 billion, at an interest rate of 7.25%. Last year, Ecuador's government signed a loan agreement for $1 billion with the China Development Bank Corp., with a fixed interest rate of 6% per year for a four-year term and an additional six-month grace period. -By Mercedes Alvaro, The Wall Street Journal [ 15-06-11 0348GMT ] Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Document DJI0000020110615e76f0007d Ecuador, China Development Bank Sign $2B Loan - Ecuador's Government 133 words 27 June 2011 05:06 PM Dow Jones Global FX & Fixed Income News CM English © 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. QUITO (Dow Jones)--Ecuador's government on Monday signed a loan for $2 billion with the China Development Bank Corp., the Finance Ministry said. The loan was signed in Beijing by Ecuador's undersecretary of Public Credit, Willian Vasconez, said the Ministry in a press release, but it didn't provide any detail. Two weeks ago, Finance Ministry Patricio Rivera said that the loan will be for eight years, with an interest rate of 6.9%, and a two- or three-year grace period. China has become the biggest source of financing for the Andean country, after it defaulted on its global bonds in 2008. -By Mercedes Alvaro, Dow Jones Newswires; 5939-9728-653; mercedes.alvaro@dowjones.com [ 06-27-11 1706ET ] Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Document CM00000020110627e76r0004s China, Ecuador Sign $2 Billion Loan Deal Mercedes Alvaro By Mercedes Alvaro 411 words 28 June 2011 05:35 AM The Wall Street Journal Online WSJO English Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. QUITO—Ecuador's government on Monday signed a loan for $2 billion with China Development Bank Corp., Ecuador's Finance Ministry said, as China deepens its financial ties with the South American nation. China, seeking to secure energy supplies, has become the largest source of financing for the Andean country, after Ecuador defaulted on its global bonds in 2008. Currently, China's loans to Ecuador exceed $6 billion, including $1.7 billion to finance 85% of Coca-Codo Sinclair, a hydropower plant to be built by China's Sinohydro Corp. in Ecuador, which will supply about 75% of the country's energy needs. The new loan was signed in Beijing by Ecuador's undersecretary of Public Credit, William Vasconez, the ministry said in a press release, without providing further detail. A person close to the negotiations told Dow Jones the $2 billion loan is connected with the sale of 39,000 barrels per day of crude and fuel oil over two years to PetroChina Co. Fernando Villavicencio, a local oil sector analyst, added that 'the loan is to be supported by the sale of oil by state oil company Petroecuador to PetroChina. This is a fact, that Petroecuador should supply oil to PetroChina for two years.' Marco Calvopina, manager of Petroecuador, said that the company is negotiating the sale of crude oil and fuel oil to PetroChina, but that it isn't linked with the $2 billion loan. 'There is not a direct relation with the loan, but we are negotiating a sale,' he said in an interview. Two weeks ago, Finance Minister Patricio Rivera said that the loan will be for eight years, with an interest rate of 6.9%, and a two- or three-year grace period. In February, Ecuador received a $1 billion prepayment from PetroChina after both agreed to renew an agreement on the supply of Ecuadorean crude oil for two years, starting in August. In July 2009, Petroecuador and PetroChina signed a similar agreement for Petroecuador to sell Oriente and Napo crude to PetroChina. In August of that year, the Andean country received an advance payment of $1 billion, at an interest rate of 7.25%. Last year, Ecuador's government signed a loan agreement for $1 billion with the China Development Bank, with a fixed interest rate of 6% per year for a four-year term and an additional six-month grace period. Dow Jones & Company, Inc. description: SUMMARY: China's Harbin Electric International Co. began building Ecuador's 275 MW Minas San Francisco hydroelectric dam in 2011. The Chinese firm is cooperating with CELEC and has financial backing from China Exim Bank. The project's total cost is $670 million, $570 million of which is covered by a line of credit from China Exim Bank. The project is expected be finished sometime in either 2015 or 2016. Duplicated by #37662 ________________________________________________________ DJ Ecuador Signs Contract With China's Harbin For Power Project 164 words 5 January 2012 07:17 PM Dow Jones Chinese Financial Wire DJCFWE English Copyright (c) 2012, Dow Jones & Company, Inc. QUITO (Dow Jones)--Corporacion Electrica del Ecuador [Celec], a state-owned power generation holding company, and China's Harbin Electric International Co. have signed a contract for the construction of Ecuador's Minas San Francisco hydroelectric project. In a statement late Wednesday, Ecuador's Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy said the project will require an investment of $477 million. Celec signed the agreement with Harbin on Dec. 30, the ministry said. The project will have a capacity of 275 MW and annual production 1,290 GWh per year, which is equivalent to about 12% of Ecuador's current production. Construction of the project is expected to take four years. The ministry didn't say when construction is scheduled to start. Chinese companies are financing or building several power projects in Ecuador. --By Paulina Escobar, Dow Jones Newswires; apaulinaescobar@yahoo.es; 593 90362817 -0- Copyright (c) 2012 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Document DJCFWE0020120106e8160005m Ecuador, Export-Import Bank of China Sign $312.5 Million Loan Deal 158 words 11 April 2013 09:05 AM Dow Jones Global Equities News DJI English (c) 2013 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. QUITO, Ecuador--The Ecuadorean government signed an agreement to receive a $312.5 million loan from the Export-Import Bank of China to help finance the Minas-San Francisco hydroelectric project, the ministry coordinator of strategic sectors said late Wednesday. The project, with a $477 million price tag, is located in Azuay and El Oro provinces. So far, the government has invested $90 million. The plant, which will have a total capacity of 275 megawatts, is expected to be completed by 2015. Once implemented, the project will reduce carbon-dioxide emissions by 680,475 tons a year, the government says. China has become the principal lender for Ecuador since 2008, when the Andean country defaulted on about $3.2 billion of global bonds. Write to Mercedes Alvaro at mercedes.alvaro@dowjones.com Subscribe to WSJ: http://online.wsj.com?mod=djnwires [ 11-04-13 1305GMT ] Dow Jones & Company, Inc. The Republic of Ecuador is the borrower on the $313 million financing that supports the 270 MW project, which has a total estimated cost of $477 million. The state utility company Corporacion Electrica del Ecuador (Celec) is the offtaker. Hogan Lovells advised Ecuador on the financing. description: SUMMARY: China's Eximbank will grant Ecuador a concessional line of credit for $80 million to expand the Simon Bolivar Avenue route to the airport in Quito. The Ministry of Finance announced the agreement on Twitter. The total project cost is $108.4 million, $80 million of which is covered by the concessional loan at 2% interest, payable in 20 years and the rest by Ecuador's State Bank and the Municipality that the road is located in. The expansion project is planned to be completed by 2016.

description: SUMMARY: Ecuador receives one of two major budge financing loans, this one for $1.4 billion (the second for $1.2 billion). China Development Bank provided the loan to the Ministry of Finance of Ecuador.This loan has a 7% interest rate, 8 year maturity, and a 2 year grace period. Ecuador should begin interest payments in 2015 and will not be payable until 2023. There is no current project for the second $1.2 billion which should be created, but its loan details are unknown.

description: CMEC signed an agreement to propose El Reventador Hydroelectric Project in Ecuador. Its estimated cost is $480 million with funding from Exim Bank and built by a Chinese consortium between CMEC and Sinohydro. While agreements were signed in June 2004, the project has not moved past its proposal. It has not been specifically suspended or cancelled and further light can be shed on its fate if the law mentioned in the articles can be found. It is also unlikely to have proceeded because of a larger dam that is under construction on the same river. UPDATE: 'Export-Import Bank of China is financing 85% through a $1.68bn loan payable in 15 years, with the remaining funds coming from the Ecuador Government.'

description: China donated 500000 mosquito nets to Ecuador to help the local Ecuadorians control epidemics. China's Ambassador to Ecuador Zeng Gang and Ecuador's foreign minister Patricio Zuquilanda exchanged notes on March 15th, 2004, and March 26th, 2004. description: SUMMARY On June 7, 2006, the government of China granted 2 credits for a total of 2.4 million USD to finance development programs in Ecuador. One credit is a refundable, no interest credit line for 1.2 million USD. These credit lines further reinforced the China-Ecuador relationship and China’s intent to follow through with its investments. STAFF_NOTE: See ID#35814 for other credit line. Specific projects funded by credit liens are unclear.

description: SUMMARY: Negotiations for a commercial loan of $1 billion from the CDB began in 2009 over CNPC's development of the ITT and Block 31. The $1 billion commercial loan has a maturity of 3-5 years and an unknown interest rate. The CDB will provide the loan to the Ministry of Finance who then will pass it on to their designated Ecuadorian firm in this case PetroAmazonas who was granted a permit to work a portion of ITT in 2014. CNPC's role is unclear bc there is no mentiion of Block 31 or ITT on their global operations website which outlines where they are active. Significant environmental controversy means poor transparency on project details. ____________________________________________________________________ China's Sinopec have offered to apply USD6 billion to develop Ecuador's ITT 284 words 11 April 2007 NoticiasFinancieras NFINCE English Copyright 2007 NoticiasFinancieras. All Rights Reserved. State-run China National PetroChemical Corporation (Sinopec) have offered Ecuadorian ex president Alfredo Palacio's administration to invest 6 billion dollars to develop exclusively the Ecuadorian oil field Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini (ITT), in the Amazonian region. Also, Sinopec proposed to split profits with Ecuadorian State 50%-50%. Sinopec proposed last year to anticipate production, with a maximum extraction target of 160,000 barrels a day in 2010. But a local commision recommended Petroecuador's Board to develop the project through a bid open to state-run companies with strategic alliances or cooperation agreements with Ecuador, in order to be adapted to the Hydrocarbons Law. Petroecuador plans to provide block, environmental, social, and economic information it has available about Block ITT and its areas of influence. Meanwhile, Petrobras, Enap, and Sinopec commit to present, jointly, a proposal to confirm the Block's reserve, development, and production. This proposal will include a preliminary development plan for the existing fields and others that may be discovered in the block, in addition to the analysis to build an up-grader plant to improve the oil produced and to build an electric plant that will use this industrial treatment unit's residues as fuel. Block ITT, which covers an area of some 190,000 hectares, is located below the easternmost portion of the Ecuadorian Amazon Region. Its main fields are Ishpingo, Tambococha, and Tiputini, among a total of five discovered there so far. China National PetroChemical Corporation (Sinopec) is China's second oil company. It is a vertically integrated firm with activities in oil, gas and chemicals industries. © 2007 NoticiasFinancieras - NoticiasFinancieras - All rights reserved Global Network Content Services LLC Document NFINCE0020070411e34b0005l Sinopec y PetroEcuador firman memorando para explotar el yacimiento ITT 532 words 26 March 2007 03:44 AM Agencia EFE - Servicio Económico EFESE Spanish Copyright 2007 Agencia EFE. All Rights Reserved Pekín, 26 mar (EFE).- Las petroleras estatales china Sinopec y ecuatoriana PetroEcuador han firmado un memorando de entendimiento (MOU) para la explotación conjunta del mayor yacimiento de Ecuador, el de Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini (ITT). El acuerdo consiste en un 'contrato de asociación, según establece la ley, en el que cada parte cuenta con un 50 por ciento', dijo hoy a Efe el embajador de Ecuador en China, Rodrigo Yepez Enríquez. El yacimiento ITT se abrió en 2005, cuenta con unas reservas estimadas de casi 5.000 millones de barriles y probadas de casi mil millones, y su explotación supone una inversión de 5.000 millones de dólares. Cuatro empresas participarán en la explotación conjunta del ITT, ya que también se cuenta con Petroleo Brasileiro SA y la chilena ENAP (Empresa Nacional de Petróleo) para ese proyecto, según informó hoy el diario chino 'Economic Information Daily'. 'Brasil y Chile participarán a través de Sinopec, ya que son subcontratistas' de esta firma, la mayor refinería de China, dijo Yepez. ITT está localizado en pleno Amazonas, y una vez iniciada su explotación se espera que su producción diaria alcance los 165.000 barriles de crudo. Tras la firma del MOU, 'ahora deben empezar a explorar para ver dónde está el petróleo exactamente, para establecer los pozos. Ese paso sería el siguiente y a continuación empezarían a explotar', aseguró el embajador. En la ceremonia de firma del MOU, en Quito, asistieron el nuevo presidente de PetroEcuador, Carlos Pareja, el ministro de Industria Raúl Sagasti, el gerente general de Sinopec en Ecuador, Ding Jingjun, y el asistente de gerencia Zhou Baixiu. Sagasti anunció durante la ceremonia otra posible inversión: 'El Gobierno de Ecuador apoya que Sinopec amplíe su inversión en el sector petrolero ecuatoriano, por lo que también desea que participe de forma activa en la licitación del proyecto petroquímico de refinado de Manta', anunció el ministro. Sinopec es una de las compañías chinas que junto con otra decena de empresas están interesadas en el proyecto de Manta, que se llevaría a cabo también en asociación con PetroEcuador, con una futura capacidad de procesado de hasta 300.000 barriles diarios y una inversión de 4.000 millones de dólares. De conseguirlo una empresa china, el resto de empresas extranjeras podrían también participar en Manta de la misma forma que lo han hecho en ITT o mediante una asociación conjunta. El proyecto de Manta fue anunciado el mes pasado por el nuevo presidente de Ecuador, el izquierdista Rafael Correa, de 43 años, quien señaló que esperaba que PetroEcuador tenga una participación del 60 por ciento. La construcción de esta planta requeriría unos cinco años. Ecuador se encuentra entre los 30 mayores productores de petróleo del mundo, el quinto de Latinoamérica, con 539.000 barriles diarios, una producción de la que exporta un 69 por ciento. Por su parte, China considera a Ecuador y Bolivia entre los nueve países calificados de 'apropiados' por el gobierno del Partido Comunista de China (PCCh, en el poder desde 1949) para que sus empresas petroleras y de gas efectúen inversiones (junto con Kuwait, Qatar, Omán, Marruecos, Libia, Níger y Noruega). EFE mz/cs Agencia EFE S.A. Document EFESE00020070326e33q000eb Chinese Sinopec, Petroecuador To Jointly Develop Ecuadorian ITT 210 words 26 March 2007 Latin America News Digest LATIND English (c) 2007 AII Data Processing Ltd. All Rights Reserved. The state-owned oil and gas companies China Petroleum & Chemical Corp (Sinopec) and Ecuadorian Petroecuador will jointly develop Ecuador's largest crude oil deposit Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini (ITT), under recently signed memorandum of understanding, media reported on March 26, 2007. The memorandum of understanding envisages an association in which each of the parties will hold 50 pct, Ecuador's Ambassador to China, Rodrigo Yepez Enriquez, said. The ITT deposit was opened in 2005 and has estimated reserves of some 5.0 billion barrels and proven reserves of almost 1.0 billion barrels of oil. The deposit's operation needs $5.0 bln (3.77 bln euro) investments. The ITT deposit will be developed also in cooperation with Brazil's state-owned oil and gas giant Petrobras and Chilean state-owned oil and gas company ENAP. ITT is located in the Amazon region and its daily output is seen at 165,000 barrels of crude oil. Ecuador was South America's fifth largest crude oil producer with some 540,000 barrels of oil per day in 2006. Crude oil is the country's largest source of revenue. (Note: One barrel = 159 litres) http://noticias.terra.com.br Source: Terra (SK/IM/SK) Aii Data Processing Limited Document LATIND0020070326e33q002s3 Sinopec to Develop Ecuador Field 189 words 27 March 2007 The Oil Daily TOILDA English (c) 2007 Energy Intelligence Group. All rights reserved. China's Sinopec has signed an agreement to jointly develop one of Ecuador's largest oil fields with three other companies, Chinese media reports said Monday. Sinopec signed a memorandum of understanding last week with state Petroecuador, Brazil's Petrobras and Chile's Enap to develop the Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini (ITT) oil field. According to Sinopec's general manager in Ecuador, Ding Jingjun, total investment for the field has been estimated at $5 billion. Earlier this month, Petroecuador indicated it would invest about $1.5 billion at some of its key fields between 2008 and 2014, much of the money going to ITT (OD Mar.15,p1). The field could potentially produce up to 165,000 b/d when it goes into production, Ding was quoted as saying. ITT is 200 miles east of Quito in the Amazon Basin. The field contains heavy crude, with reserves of about 4 billion bbl, of which 1 billion bbl are thought recoverable. Spain's Repsol YPF and India's Oil and Natural Gas Corp. were also reportedly interested in the project (OD Jul.20,p7). Energy Intelligence Group Inc Document TOILDA0020070403e33r00008 Ecuador's ITT could reach 752,500 b/d of heavy crude STEPHAN KUEFFNER Stephan Kueffner skueffner@gmail.com, Stephan Kueffner 979 words 30 August 2013 Platts Oilgram News PON ISSN: 0163-1284, Volume 91, Issue 171 English (c) 2013 McGraw-Hill, Inc. Ecuador's crude oil output could reach a peak of 752,500 b/d in 2019 if the contentious development of the Ishpingo-Tiputini-Tambococha heavy crude field goes ahead, according to government documents obtained by Platts Wednesday. This is about 30% higher than country's record daily output of 540,000 b/d reached on July 29. The documents form the basis of the request by president Rafael Correa to the National Assembly to be allowed to develop the field inside the Yasuni National Park, an Amazon rainforest preserve which is home to one of the world's most diverse animal and plant habitats. 'We're definitely facing a project that guarantees a sustainable development model, environmentally balanced and respectful of cultural diversity, and with the firm commitment of conserving biodiversity and ensuring the satisfaction of the fundamental needs of our country's inhabitants,' Correa wrote in his request. Under the 2008 constitution that he championed, congress must approve oil development in protected areas. Correa tasked the oil, economy, justice, and environment ministries with writing documents to support the request for development of the oil field, after dropping an environmental plan to keep the field's oil underground on August 15. According to the oil ministry's report, the ITT field holds a proven 607 million barrels of crude, with 917.7 million proven and probable reserves, divided nearly equally between the Ishpingo and the Tiputini-Tambococha areas. The field holds total possible reserves of up to 1.3 billion barrels, the ministry estimated, but it used the 917.7 million barrel figure as the basis for the government's projections for output and revenue. Current technology would allow Petroamazonas, the upstream unit of state oil company Petroecuador, to extract 91% of the oil, or 838 million barrels, from the field. Investment through 2022 would cost $5.59 billion, without including any eventual cleanup costs, while production is estimated to last 23 years. Average output costs for the ITT field would run at $12/barrel. Moving the heavy, 14-degree API oil to port near Esmeraldas on the Pacific Ocean would cost $1.46/b. Pipelines to be built Petroamazonas aims to build 30 kilometers of main pipelines within the park and another 81.5 kilometers south of the Napo River to its liquids separation plant on Block 12 at Eden-Yuturi, where the ITT crude would be mixed with lighter crude from Blocks 12 and 31. While the government's request for permission to extract oil from the park includes Block 31, Petroamazonas began to develop that block's Apaika-Nenke field in early 2012, without congressional approval. The report cites a 2010 Ryder Scott estimate for Block 31 reserves of 279.4 million barrels. In a separate news report Wednesday, Petroamazonas head Oswaldo Madrid said Block 31 could produce 18,000-20,000 b/d from 20 wells, according to official government newswire Andes. If development of the ITT field begins next year as currently planned, the Tambococha area, which lies outside the park and under the Napo River, could start pumping oil in 2016, followed eight months later by Tiputini and then by Ishpingo in 2018. Tiputini output would peak at 62,000 b/d in 2017, Tambococha at 110,000 b/d in its fourth year, and Ishpingo at 130,000 b/d in its seventh year. Combined, the ITT is projected to reach peak output of 200,000 b/d in 2018 or 2019, requiring three production platforms each at Tiputini and Tambococha and five at Ishpingo. Development would include a total of 360 oil wells—300 inside the national park—and at least three platforms for the reinjection of formation water. Pipelines would run underground and be fitted with safeguards to cause automatic shutdowns in the event of accidents. Access roads would be 10 meters wide, according to the oil ministry report. The government estimates that it would break even on the ITT project in 2016. It would gain $41.77 billion from the field through 2036, according to its base scenario, assuming average prices of $70/b for the oil. Ecuador has, however, also received Chinese funds in loans backed in oil called 'advance oil sales' by the government. This month, it received another Chinese loan for $1.2 billion backed in oil at an undisclosed interest rate. Similar earlier deals have had an interest rate near 7%. Protests sparked Correa's decision to go ahead with developing the ITT field after six years of campaigning against it has sparked protests among environmentalists and indigenous organizations. Demonstrations have drawn hundreds in numerous cities, including Quito, the capital. Correa argues that Ecuador needs the ITT's revenue to help combat poverty. Critics point to Ecuador's 40-year experience producing oil, which has not eliminated poverty, and which has saddled some areas with oil-related pollution and sparked a controversial lawsuit against US oil major Chevron. Besides demanding congressional approval for oil production and mining in protected areas, Ecuador's constitution also bans any such activity in the territories of its two remaining isolated Amazon indigenous tribes. While it was promoting the environmental option to leave the ITT undeveloped, the government said these tribes inhabited the ITT/Block 43 area, some 40% of which is outside the park to the north and in a strip along the border with Peru. In the new documents submitted to congress, however, the justice ministry denies any evidence of their presence in the areas slated for development. The Ishpingo deposit's southern end juts into an 'intangible' area of the Yasuni park in which any economic activity is banned. Stephan Kueffner skueffner@gmail.com, Stephan Kueffner Ecuador’s Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini (ITT) field The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc. Document PON0000020130927e98u0000e

description: In March 2002, China agreed to grant Ecuador 40 million US dollars in loans and three million dollars in emergency aid to help it recover from recent natural disaster. description: In March 2002, recruiting began for young volunteers for six-month tours of aid service in Laos, China's first youth volunteer project abroad. The initial five volunteers will include one Chinese language teacher, an English language teacher, an expert in computer training and two medical staff. After some training the new recruits will set off by the end of April. They will be provided with travelling expenses, room and board, necessary allowances and insurance. The team arrived in Laos on May 22 and returned to China on July 11.

description: China built a cultural palace in Vientiane for Laos, The National Palace of Culture, in 2004. It was reported as part of a larger package of projects: China has granted non-refundable aid worth 300 million Chinese Yuan and a credit of 690 million Chinese Yuan to Laos' key projects. According to the 'New Vientiane' newspaper, China has invested USD 120 million in 90 investment projects in Laos. Some of the projects have been put into operation. They include two hydro-electric power plants in Phongsali and Oudomsay provinces, a cow breeding project in Bokeo province, a national cultural palace in Vientiane capital, Vang Vieng Cement Plant No.2, a plant to produce packages for cement, and a 100-patient bed hospital in Luang Prabang province. STAFF_NOTE: It is is unclear if some of the 300 million Yuan grant or 690 million Yuan credit was used for the palace, hence the amount is left out of Transaction. The youth trip to China is accounted for in Project ID #33680.
sector_comment: National Cultural Palace in Vientiane capital

description: On 24 May 2002, China pledged to provide more technical assistance to Laos in carrying out drug control programmes, specifically covering the training of drug control officials and the provision of alternative crops to replace opium. At a recent meeting for Chinese and Lao drug control officials in Beijing, the two sides outlined methods to strengthen cooperation and the exchange of drug-related information, the development of alternative crops, and to curb drug abuse to combat the problem. In furtherance of the agreement, China has opened a 30-day course on drug control for 30 Lao security officers in China's Yunnan province. STAFF_NOTE: The 2005 article mentions that the 2002 course had been completed.

donor_agency: China Ministry of Public Security, Government Agency

description: China has reportedly built a 100-patient bed hospital in Luang Prabang province. The project was reported concurrently with several other activities. It was mentioned in broader reports that China has granted non-refundable aid worth 300 million Chinese Yuan and a credit of 690 million Chinese Yuan to Laos's key projects. According to the 'New Vientiane' newspaper report in 2002, China has invested USD 120 million in 90 investment projects in Laos. Some of the projects have been put into operation. They include two hydro-electric power plants in Phongsali and Oudomsay provinces, a cow breeding project in Bokeo province, a national cultural palace in Vientiane capital, Vang Vieng Cement Plant No.2, a plant to produce packages for cement. STAFF_NOTE: This project is made up of many different projects, for which it is unclear if 300 million Yuan grant or 690 million Yuan credit was used. Transaction amount or flow type unclear.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=vietna0020020713dy3t000cu&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

description: China reportedly agreed to assist Laos with cow breeding in 2002. The project was mentioned as part of a larger package wherein China granted non-refundable aid worth 300 million Chinese Yuan and a credit of 690 million Chinese Yuan to Laos's key projects. According to the 'New Vientiane' newspaper report in 2002, China has invested USD 120 million in 90 investment projects in Laos. Some of the projects have been put into operation. They include two hydro-electric power plants in Phongsali and Oudomsay provinces, a cow breeding project in Bokeo province, a national cultural palace in Vientiane capital, Vang Vieng Cement Plant No.2, a plant to produce packages for cement, and a 100-patient bed hospital in Luang Prabang province. STAFF_NOTE: It is unclear if 300 million Yuan grant or 690 million Yuan credit was used at all for the breeding project. Transaction amount, flow type and organization involved are unclear.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=vietna0020020713dy3t000cu&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; ftp://ftp.cgiar.org/ilri/ICT/Theme%203/adb_livestock_review.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

description: On March 9, 2003, China sent the second youth volunteer team to Laos to help with Chinese and English language teaching, medical and computer training, and business administration. The 10-person team was the first team organized by Shanghai. The team returned to China on September 9.

description: On October 22, 2003, China sent the third youth volunteer team to Laos to help with Chinese and English language teaching, music, medical, computer, and agricultural training, and business administration. The 13-person team was the second team organized by Shanghai. The team returned to China on April 22, 2004.

description: China has successfully finished a geological survey for Kalium resources in the Vientiane Plain of Laos. The project, implemented by the Yunnan Geology and Mineral Resources Exploitation Group Company, has been jointly approved by the Chinese and Lao governments and co-funded by China's Ministries of Finance and Land Resources, the former State Development Planning Commission and the company. In March 2000, the company detected a rich Kalium reserve allowing an initial exploitation of 100 million tons and a maximum possible reserve of 10 billion tons from a land area of 1,970 square kilometers. STAFF_NOTE: Financial details are unclear.

description: An agreement of grant assistance was signed on 25 August at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Laos between Sayyakan Soulivong, head of the ASEAN Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and Shen Yueming, assistant to the director-general of the Yunnan Corporation for International Technology and Economic Cooperation of China. Under the agreement, China will provide Laos with 13 million yuan worth of grant aid to host the 10th ASEAN Summit which will be held at the end of this year. The grant aid comprises five vans, five ambulances, 20 police cars and some safety inspection devices.

description: The Chinese Women Union (CWU) has donated aid items worth US$36,144 to the Lao Women Union (LWU) recently. The items, including 15 personal computers, 76 sewing machines and some copy machines, were presented to LWU President Onechanh Thammavong on 28 October. Chinese Ambassador to Laos Mr Liu Yong Xing said at the presentation ceremony that these aid items would go to promoting the traditional Lao art of silk weaving amongst Lao women. On the same occasion, Mrs Onechanh thanked the CWU for their generosity and she hoped that would be more opportunities for cooperation in future.

description: The Nam Mang 3 hydroelectric project in Vientiane was completed in 2004. The cost of the project was 537 billion kip. It was funded 80% by loans from China EXIM Bank (429.6 billion kip) and 20% by EDL (107.4 billion kip). Specifically, a European Parliament study states that Eximbank financed the project through an export seller's credit. Construction was led by China International Water and Electric Corporation.

description: The Chinese government has pledged grant aid for improvement to the Patuxai Park and provision of office equipment. The signing ceremony for the grant aid took place on 19 November at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 19 November. The grant aid comprises two parts: office equipment worth 1.9 million yuan to the Lao People Revolutionary Party Central administrative office; and 10 million yuan for the Patuxai Park improvement project. This grant aid was part of the Chinese government's contribution to the success of the ASEAN Summit, ASEAN + 3 and ASEAN + 1 meetings. The Agreement was co-signed by Deputy Prime Minister Mr Somsavad Lengsavat and Chinese Ambassador to Laos Mr Liu Yong Xing.

description: China has granted 86,639 USD in aid to help Laos buy treatment medication for drug addicts. The aid hand-over was made at a ceremony which was attended by Linthong Phetsavanh, Head of Lao National Commission for Drug Control and Supervision and Anguojun, Deputy Secretary of the Chinese Committee for Drug Control. The money will be used to construct a drug addict treatment and rehabilitation centre in Oudomsay province and to help train centre staff and supply necessary medicines.

description: On 12 June 2005, China signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Laos to develop the latter's Internet, mobile phone and Cable TV. The signatories were President of Laos' Economic Development Fund and Director of Beijng's New Technology Development Department. Under the MOU, the Chinese company will start construction of the necessary infrastructure within 90 days. Laos, on the other hand, would give its fullest support to the project. description: On 22 Aug 2006 the Lao government agreed to let state-owned Chinese corporation Yunnan United Antimony Industry carry out an antimony ore survey and exploration project in Luang Prabang province. It is expected to cost US$1.6 million. The project will run for an estimated 18 months, and Lao officials believe that both sides will see mutual benefits in the near future. This agreement forms part of the cooperative framework between the Lao and Chinese governments for developing the mining sector in Laos.

description: In October 2006, Laos and China signed the Memorandum of Understanding for the Nam Khan 2 & 3 hydropower plants. In August 2009, Sinohydro Corporation, China's largest builder of hydropower plants, signed a contract with Laos' electricity supplier, Electricite Du Laos (EDL) to build two hydropower stations and a power transmission line in a deal that is cumulatively worth around US$559 million. Sinohydro will have an initial ownership of 85% while EDL will have an initial ownership of 15% in the project. The contracts included the construction of a 230-kV power transmission line from Xieng Khouang to Luang Prabang city, which is the major part of Laos' 2020 national grid network plan. China Exim Bank will finance the project with a preferential loan. The construction cost of Nam Khan 2 hydropower plant was US$308.5 million and has been loaned by the China Exim Bank at an interest rate of 2 percent per year. The duration of the loan is 20 years. Construction on the plant began on November 26, 2011, and is scheduled for completion in September 2015. STAFF_NOTE: details on loan regarding Nam Khan 3 power plant unknown STAFF_NOTE: contradictory transaction amounts (Sinohydro: US$314m in contractual value)

description: The Lao-Chinese Friendship Centre will be built in Vientiane to serve people in the capital city and surrounding areas, according to the Lao News Agency (KPL). The 174,000 square metre project is part of a cooperation framework on trade and investment between the Lao and Chinese governments. The 18 million USD project, which will be built near Dong Pasak guesthouse, will help boost socio-economic development and the provision of quality goods at cheap prices to the Lao people, according to Ting Koua Chieng, the project's managing director. It will include be a complex including hotel, guesthouse, public park, trade centre, restaurant and market. 80% of imported goods are expected to come from China. In 2008, it was reported that the construction of the shopping mall has been completed. Current status of the entire project is unclear. STAFF_NOTE: Exact details of joint venture unclear.

description: China is to provide neighbouring Laos with a package of assistance, of preferential loans and exchange of notes, covering agricultural machinery, finance and training under an agreement signed by the two countries on 30 June 2006. The agreement was announced in a joint communique on the week-long state visit by general secretary of the Central Committee of the Lao People's Revolutionary Party and Lao President Choummali Sai-Gnason, a guest of Chinese President Hu Jintao. STAFF_NOTE: Exact quantity of goods or transaction amount were not specified.

Construction started in May 2010 and finished in August 2011. An inauguration ceremony was held on August 14, 2013.

description: In 2007, China provided Laos with 500,000 USD to help build a drug detoxification centre in Oudomxay and its nearby provinces. A hand-over ceremony was held in Vientiane last weekend between Chinese Ambassador to Laos Pan Quang Xue and Minister to the Presidential Palace and Chairman of the National Committee for Drug Control and Supervision Suban Salithilath. The Chinese Ambassador also donated 100,000 USD for road construction and the installation of an electricity system for the centre. China's Deputy Secretary of the Committee for Drug Control and Suppression, Yang Feng Rui, also presented medicine worth 500,000 Yuan to the Lao National Committee for Drug Control and Supervision. STAFF_NOTE: It is unsure whether the last two donations where made in their official or personal capacity.

description: In 2007, China agreed to build a 94,298 square meters, 20,000-seater sports stadium in Vien Chang for the hosting of the 2009 Southeast Asian Games. It will employ about 3,000 Chinese construction workers to do so. It was completed and opened in 2009. The China Development Bank agreed to provide a concessional loan of US $100 million to build the sports stadium on the surety of a land concession. Construction was conducted by Yunnan Construction Engineering Co. The stadium also includes two 3,000-seater gymnasium and swimming pool, warm-up pool, tennis court, shooting gallery and outdoor training grounds. STAFF_NOTE: conflicting transaction amount from different sources (some say US$100m, the Chinese Embassy site says approximately US$90m), the updated one is from the Chinese Embassy website

description: Countries and international organisations have financed and supplied technical facilities to Laos in response to the Lao government for help in their fight against bird flu. The Laos-based Chinese Embassy granted 50,000 USD through the Lao Bird Flu Prevention Fund.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=THAINS0020070326e33r0008u&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks

description: In December 2007, the Deputy President of Sinohydro Corporation presented a cheque for US$100,000 to the Governor of Phongsaly province. This money was to be used to improve television and radio reception in Phongsaly province.
sources: http://www.apu.ac.jp/rcaps/uploads/fckeditor/publications/journal/RJAPS_V27_Fujimura.pdf, Academic Journal Article

donor_agency: Sinohydro Corporation, State-Owned Company

description: The Lao Government has borrowed over 570 billion kip (US$57.8 million) from Exim Bank of China to invest in rebuilding Luang Prabang's International Airport. China CAMC Engineering Co Ltd will be responsible for the survey, design and construction of the rebuilding project, expected to be over within 45 months. The reconstruction works include new runway with a length of 2,800m and width of 45m and building two taxiways to access the aircraft hangar of the airport. The development plan also includes the rehabilitation of the hanger to be able to hold four Boeing 737s or ATR 320s.

description: In April 2008, Laos conducted a feasibility study of a rail link from Vientiane to Thakhek, and onto Muya in Vietnam to connect to the Vietnam Railway Network. The study was funded by the Chinese government with the participation of a group of twelve Chinese technical staff. Vientiane Times reported that the estimated cost of the study was $100,000, and that the study was underway and expected to be completed by the first week of April 2008.
sources: http://www.apu.ac.jp/rcaps/uploads/fckeditor/publications/journal/RJAPS_V27_Fujimura.pdf, Academic Journal Article; http://www.mysinchew.com/node/9368, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mfa.gov.cn/chn//pds/ziliao/tytj/t419061.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: Soochow University was founded in Vientiane, Laos on July 2011. The Chinese government started funding scholarships to the university as early as September 2008.
sources: http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20121004161503207, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://eng.suda.edu.cn/html/Cooperation/Laos/, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.apu.ac.jp/rcaps/uploads/fckeditor/publications/journal/RJAPS_V27_Fujimura.pdf, Academic Journal Article

description: In August 2008, Mekong River flooding caused serious damage along the river areas from the north to the south of Laos. In response, the Chinese government donated approximately US$100,000 to the Lao government to help the people affected by the disaster.
sources: http://www.apu.ac.jp/rcaps/uploads/fckeditor/publications/journal/RJAPS_V27_Fujimura.pdf, Academic Journal Article

description: On 28 January 2008 Laos and China have signed a Memorandum of Understanding on Nam Ngum Downstream hydropower project in Pakngum district, Vientiane Capital. Signatories were Deputy Minister of Planning and Investment Thongmy Phommyxay and the chairman of the China National Electronics Import-Export Corporation Cong Ya Dong. The company will conduct a survey and feasibility study on the development of the Nam Ngum downstream hydropower project for 18 months. Construction started in 2010 and is expected to finish in 2014. STAFF_NOTE: Feasibility study & building agreement were signed on the same day. Also, there are no sources confirming transaction amount or the completion of the project in 2014. Unsure which Nam Ngum hydropower plant this project is referring to.

description: China has agreed to invest in the Xepone 3 hydropower project. The MOU was signed on April 21 2008, with little information about its expected completion date or the project's financing. It is known that state-owned China National Machinery & Equipment Import & Export Corporation would be involved in the project.

description: In 2009, China donated Computers and Camera Equipment worth 44,000 USD to the Laotian National Assembly. The donation is to increase capacity and efficiency in the Assembly.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=OANA000020090804e529009h3&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:bHYTjKH4_gAJ:www.kpl.net.la/english/news/newsrecord/06.02.09/edn2.htm+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.apu.ac.jp/rcaps/uploads/fckeditor/publications/journal/RJAPS_V27_Fujimura.pdf, Academic Journal Article

description: In 2009, China granted 344 billion kip for road resurfacing on Road No. 13 in Northern Laos. The grant is also intended for drainage system improvements and repairs to five bridges. It was scheduled for completion in 2011, but the status is unknown.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=THAINS0020090122e51n0008m&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.apu.ac.jp/rcaps/uploads/fckeditor/publications/journal/RJAPS_V27_Fujimura.pdf, Academic Journal Article

description: A new series of bridges on the Mekong River will complete the north-south corridor in the Greater Mekong Sub-region (GMS), creating a roadway that will link China to the various nations of South-East Asia: Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand and Vietnam. Lao state media reported on May 25, 2010 that China would provide a US$50 million loan for the construction of a bridge near the Lao town of Pakbeng, in the Southeast Asian country's northern Oudomxay province and across from northern Thailand.
sources: http://la.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/hzjj/201212/20121208480258.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.atimes.com/atimes/China/LF18Ad02.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.asianews.it/news-en/New-Mekong-bridges-linking-China-to-SE-Asia-get-green-light-18757.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofa.gov.la/index.php/site-map-2/2013-11-14-04-21-27/46-statements/speeches/154-remarks-by-h-e-mr-thongsing-thammavong-prime-minister-of-lao-pdr-at-the-opening-ceremony-of-the-21st-world-economic-forum-31-may-2012-bangkok-thailand, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=ItF5BgAAQBAJ&dq=china+development+bank+loan+%24100+million+laos+stadium&source=gbs_navlinks_s, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

description: Lao Airlines State Enterprise (LASE) will spend about 134 billion kip (US$16.7 million) to build a Lao Airlines aircraft hangar and a Maintenance and Training Centre to maintain high levels of safety. The project is being financed by a preferential loan from the Chinese government and will run for 18 months from November 15, 2010, to March 15, 2012. The loan amount also covers the development strategy of the Lao national carrier over the next ten years or till 2020, according to Director General of the Lao Airlines state enterprise Somphone Douangmala.
sources: http://la.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/hzjj/201206/20120608196195.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://en.vietstock.vn/2011/01/lao-airliness-new-hangar-under-construction-143-103147.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://en.baomoi.com/Info/New-facilities-to-boost-Lao-Airlines-standards/3/105095.epi, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://la.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t788635.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
funding_agency: Yunnan Construction Engineering Group Corporation (YNJG)
donor_agency: Yunnan Construction Engineering Group Corporation (YNJG)
contacts: Zhao Wenyu, Commercial Counselor

description: The Lao government has financed the project through a bank loan from the Chinese government amounting to more than US$103 million, of which US$31.5 million is for the development of the first tailrace and US$71.6 million is for the fourth tailrace. The US $31.5 million project has been 95 per cent funded by a loan from the Chinese government, with the remaining coming from the Lao government's joint fund. China-based Norinco International is undertaking construction. Irrigation Department Director General, Maykong Phonephommavong, said the project would supply water to 2,700 hectares of rice fields in 10 villages as well as for cash crop plantations and livestock operations. STAFF_NOTE: This project is the construction of outlets at the Nam Theun 2 dam to irrigate cultivation land, not the construction of the dam itself. STAFF_NOTE: Details unclear over the $103 million loan; breakdown given only for $31.5 million for the first tailrace.

description: In June 16, 2010, it was reported that China Southern Power Grid has reached agreements with the government of Laos to build a national power grid and a hydropower plant. The state-owned monopoly power distributor in China's five southern provinces signed a memorandum of understanding with Lao's Ministry of Planning and Investment on investment in and construction of a grid network in Laos, and an agreement to develop the Nam Tha 1 hydropower project. According to Xinhua in 2011, the Chinese side has completed the feasibility study and research reports for the project and submitted them to the Lao government. Current status of project is unclear, and as of December 2011, it was reported that China has completed a feasibility study of the project, franchise model studies and research reports which have been submitted to the Laos government. It is awaiting approval before project development and construction can begin.

description: The China-aided Lao International Convention Center (ICC) was completed ahead of schedule in Oct 2012. The construction started on Dec. 31 last year and was scheduled in the contract to complete on Oct. 30. Conference center covers an area of about 7 hectares, the construction area of nearly 25,000 square meters, and can accommodate more than 3,000 people for meetings. The convention centre is being funded by a 450 million yuan (about US$70.3 million) loan from the Chinese government and was designed by the Institute of Project Planning and Research under the Machinery Industry Ministry of China.

description: The Nam Ngiep 2 hydropower station is a joint venture between the state-owned China International Water & Electric Corp (CWE) and Lao National Power Corporation worth $345 million. China Development Bank funded 80% while CWE funded 20%. It is located in the southeastern province of Xieng Khouang Charles plains, about 70 kilometers from the provincial capital of Phonsavan, and has a total installed capacity of 180,000 kilowatts. The project was completed in April 2015, with Minister of Energy and Mines, Mr Soulivong Daravong, Chief Engineer of China International Water and Electric Corporation, Mr Chen Xianming, Deputy Managing Director of EDL, Mr Thongphet Doangngeun, and the deputy governors of Xieng Khuang and Xaysomboun provinces attending the impoundment ceremony.

description: An airport expansion and upgrade project was initiated by the Ministry of Public Works and Transport of Laos in association with China CAMC Engineering Company in July 2011. The project included the expansion of the runway by 260m, development of the parking space, renovation of the drainage system, and road upgrades. It also included the expansion of 02 and 03 aprons at the airport for accommodating larger aircraft. New office buildings for the Lao Civil Aviation Department and the LAA were also built. The total expansion investment was Kip302bn ($37.68m). Ground was broken for the construction works of the expansion project in December 2011 and it was completed in October 2012.
sources: http://la.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/hzjj/201210/20121008378399.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.airport-technology.com/projects/wattay-international-airport-vientiane/, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://la.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t977859.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.camce.com.cn/en/project/traffic/1302495545-97.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
