description: In June 2010, Thailand and China signed the Traditional Medical Center Project Design Arrangement, which includes the construction of a two-story building located in tsunami-hit Phuket island. The building covers an area of 3,163 square km and provides services, such as traditional Chinese medicine, acupuncture, Thai massage, foot treatment, as well as meeting room, shop and restaurant. The project will cost 6.7 million RMB. STAFF_NOTE: Unsure if amount is amount China provided or overall cost. STAFF_NOTE: This project might be linked to #34122

description: In October 2011, the Chinese government provided emergency humanitarian aid to Thailand for relief efforts in flood-ravaged Thai regions. The Chinese emergency humanitarian aid to the Thailand government includes 1 million U.S. dollars in cash remittance and 10 million yuan (1.57 million U.S. dollars) worth of relief materials. Interior Minister Mr. Yongyuth Wichaidit said the in-kind relief materials include amphibious boats, water pumping machines and solar-energy flash lights.

description: In April 2011 China Red Cross gave a $30,000 cash grant to Thaland Red Cross to help the Thai people against flooding.

recipient_agencies: Red Cross Society of Thailand, National NGO

description: In October 2011, China pledged to donate $1.5 million in flood relief supplies to Thailand. The donation was received on October 13 2011. The aid package was made up of 64 speed and rubber boats, and 60 sets of water purifying equipment.
sources: http://english.cntv.cn/20111013/103577.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.asean-cn.org/Item/3771.aspx, Media Report, including Wikileaks

description: In October 2011, China donated $4.7 million in flood relief supplies to Thailand. The donation was received on October 21 2011. The aid package was made up of 20,000 long-sleeve shirts, 1300 tents, 30 speed boats, 30 sets of water-purifying equipment and 8,000 sandbags.
sources: http://english.cntv.cn/20111021/102769.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks

description: In December 2011, China announced plans to donate 100 tablet computers to Thai students as a trial. This project is the trial version of the agreement in #38175.

contacts: Thitima Chaisang, Chinese government spokeswoman

description: The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration (BMA) has received assistance money from two Chinese cities and two Japanese cities worth over Bt28 million for flood-hit communities in February 2012. BMA had a created a project to aid flood-hit communities by using funds from the city's 'Together We Can' fund, which received donations from Chongqing, China (25 million Baht), Beijing, (1.5 million Baht), Tokyo, Japan (1.5 million Baht) and Chiba prefecture's Yashio city in Japan (680,000 Baht). The money would be distributed to 616 communities in 21 districts that were declared disaster-hit areas with flooding of over-80cm-deep.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=THAINS0020120207e8280002w&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.nationmultimedia.com/national/Bt28m-from-China-Japan-30175290.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Wasan Meewong, Bangkok Metropolitan Administration Spokesman

description: On March 15, 2012, a team of traditional Chinese physicians arrived in Bangkok to provide free medical consultations. On March 17, the team arrived in Phuket Island and provided free medical consultations. The doctors were organized by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office and the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office in Guangdong Province.
sources: http://gocn.southcn.com/news2010/201203/t20120323_256849.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/overseas/2012-03/19/c_122853890.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gqb.gov.cn/news/2012/0319/25802.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: In April 2012, China and Thailand signed an Establishing a Comprehensive Strategic Cooperative Partnership, under which they pledged to take concrete measures to implement the Joint Action Plan on Thailand – China Strategic Cooperation and the Memorandum of Understanding on Cooperation on Sustainable Development in Thailand, as well as to advance pragmatic cooperation in various fields.
sources: http://www.mfa.go.th/main/en/media-center/14/39995-Joint-Press-Statement-on-Long-Term-Program--on-the.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: In April 2012, China agreed to send water experts to Thailand to work with its flood and water management committee. The experts will be drawn from 17 ministries and companies and advise Thailand on floods and droughts.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=THAINS0020120429e84u0001k&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/290932/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2012-03/14/c_131467199.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: China Ministry of Water Resources, Government Agency
donor_agency: China Ministry of Water Resources, Government Agency

description: In December 2014, China agreed to provide technology to help agricultural development in Thailand. Under the agreement, China’s satellite navigation system will be used for geospatial disaster monitoring, assessment and forecasting in Thailand. The agreement is meant to facilitate the development of the Thai Geospatial Information Industry Park. The financial value and nature of Chinese funding of this project are unknown.
sources: http://th.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201412/20141200849220.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/hqgj/jryw/2014-12-25/content_12942923.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

description: In January 2015, China announced plans to provide loans to Thailand for railway construction. Several options were offered, such as a 100b Baht loan through the Bank of China at an interest rate of 3% and a repayment period of 20 years, and a 2b Baht loan through an unnamed bank at an interest rate of 2.9% and a repayment period of 2.9%. The present status of this project is unknown.
sources: http://th.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201501/20150100862046.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: On July 9th 2013, China and Uganda signed an agreement for a technical and economic cooperation grant worth 50 million RMB ( about 8.2 million USD). Zhao Yali, the Chinese ambassador to Uganda stated the money would be used toward agriculture, infrastructure and human resource development projects. According to Maria Kiwanuka, the specifics will be agreed upon by the two governments in the near future. The grant is a fulfillment of a promise made to President Museveni when he met with the Chinese President, Xi Jinping, during the emerging economies of Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa (BRICS) summit in South Africa, earlier this year. The current state of this project is unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=MENREP0020130711e97b000gu&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.observer.ug/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=26319:china-gives-uganda-82-million-grant, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Zhao Yali, Chinese ambassador ; Maria Kiwanuka, Finance minister

description: China has been sending medical teams to Uganda since 1983. Yunnan Province has been responsible for sending the teams. In August 2013, the 16th medical team of 8 members arrived in Uganda. The team works at the China-Uganda Friendship Hospital in Kampala. STAFF_NOTE: One of the resources is the official blog of the members of the 16th medical team.

description: On March 26, 2013, the Communist Party of China donated 40 laptop and 90 desktop computers to the National Resistance Movement Party in Uganda. They also included computer accessories such as printers in the donation. The visiting Chinese delegation was led by the Vice Minister of International Department of the CPC Central Committee, Chen Fengxian.
sources: http://opm.go.ug/news-archive/communist-party-of-china-donates-computer-equipment-to-nrm.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: On June 20, 2014, China delivered anti-malaria medicine, equipment, and supplies to the malaria center in Uganda at the China-Uganda Friendship Hospital. The original agreement of the donation was signed in 2013.
sources: http://blog.sina.com.cn/s/blog_d19558450102v50r.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://ug.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201406/20140600638057.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: On November 12, 2013, the 16th Chinese medical team donated a batch of medicine and medical equipment to the China-Uganda Friendship Hospital.
sources: http://blog.sina.com.cn/s/blog_d19558450101gp88.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

description: The Chinese Government offered 40 scholarships for talented Ugandan students to pursue education in China and provide 404 slots of training courses for Ugandan government officials in various sectors. Chinese ambassador, Zhao Yali made the pledge at a media reception held at the Chinese embassy in Kampala.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020130418e94i0018m&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.newvision.co.ug/news/641794-china-offers-40-scholarships-for-ugandan-students.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Zhao Yali, Chinese Ambassador to Uganda

description: In 2012, the Chinese government signed an agreement with Uganda for a 26 billion UGX interest-free loan for implementing unidentified development programs. The loan agreement was signed by the Chinese ambassador to Uganda, Zhao Yali, and the Ugandan Minister of Finance, Planning and Economic Development, Fred Jachan Omach. A 20 billion UGX grant was signed at the same time (ID#30256).
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020121020e8ak000dy&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.newvision.co.ug/news/636597-china-gives-uganda-sh46b.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: Fred Jachan Omach, Ugandan Minister of Finance ; Zhao Yali, Chinese Ambassador to Uganda

description: In 2012, the Chinese government secured 90,000 USD for the construction of a Chinese school in Uganda at Luyanzi College located in Bweyogerere in Wakiso district. The school will house a Chinese information and cultural center which will be open to the business community and public as an information resource center. The Chairman of Uganda China Friendship Association, Somma Ayub, said they had acquired 400 acres for construction of the facility that will include a kindergarten, primary, secondary school, teaching hospital and polytechnic.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020120412e84b000m0&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks
implementing_agency: Uganda China Friendship Association, Public Private Partnership
contacts: Somma Ayub, (Uganda China Friendship Association); Jimmy Dhiyongera, School Headmaster ; Mamerito Mugerwa, Mayor of Kiira ; Zhao Ya Li, Chinese Ambassador to Uganda

description: In January 2012, China began donating road equipment district units worth 130,520 USD to Uganda. According to the Ugandan Aid Management Platform, the project is still ongoing. The commitment date for this project is unknown.
sources: http://aiddata.org/opening-development#uganda_crowdsourcing, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: In a 2011/12 annual performance report, the Ugandan government reported that the Chinese government provided scholarships to train Ugandan industrial workers. The scholarship grant aid went to teaching Ugandan workers in specific industrial skills; originally the Ugandan government planned for one staff person to be trained, but the grant allowed seven individuals to receive training.
sources: http://opm.go.ug/manage/pdfs2013/GAPR2011_12V2.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: On May 5, 2011, the Ugandan parliament approved a 350 million USD concessional loan with two percent interest from China's Exim Bank for the construction of a toll road from Entebbe Airport to the capital Kampala. The road is expected to cost 476 million USD, with 126 million USD of the funding coming from the Ugandan government. The loan from China required that the consulting and construction companies used for the project be Chinese. The China Communications Construction Company (CCCC) was chosen to implement the project. The four-lane highway will feature at least four toll stations. It also will include four interchanges with overpasses, along with a connection to the new highway to Munyonyo, Uganda�s major international conference destination. The link between the new highway and Munyonyo will include a 3-km-long, two-lane bridge constructed to run over a Nile River marshland that cuts across the proposed road link. Construction was expected to begin around July 2012, with the project taking three years to complete. On November 21, 2012, President Yoweri Museveni Wednesday officially launched the project at a ground-breaking ceremony at Kyengera, off the Kampala-Masaka road. According to an executive of the Uganda National Roads Authority, Peter Ssebanakitta, the first 6km of the road have been handed over to the contractor to start work. Compensation of residents affected by the construction is underway, with 250 people so far paid. The most recently found update from Red Pepper in 2014 states that CCCC is to construct an additional 9 km, but stated the project would cost 150 million USD.

description: In 2011, China offered Uganda an interest-free loan of 100 million CNY to be used for projects that will be mutually agreed upon by both governments in the future. The signing ceremony took place in the Ministry of Finance boardroom and was attended by the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr. Chris Kassami and his deputy, Mr. Keith Muhakanizi. Both the current status and the specific use of the loan are unknown. Another agreement for a 100 million CNY grant was signed at the same time (ID #30224).
sources: http://www.finance.go.ug/images/docs/Chinese%20Govt%20Offers%20Financial%20Grant.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Keith Muhakanizi, Deputy Secretary to the Treasury (Ugandan Government); Chris Kassami, Secretary to the Treasury (Ugandan Government); Zhao Yali, Chinese Ambassador to Uganda (China Ministry of Foreign Affairs)

description: China has been sending medical teams to Uganda since 1983. Yunnan Province has been responsible for sending the teams. On August 2011, the 15th medical team of 8 members arrived at the Jinja Hospital in Uganda. They team moved to the China-Uganda Friendship Hospital in June 2012 and completed their two-year mission in August 2013.
sources: http://www.moh.gov.cn/gjhzs/dyhbz/201308/38f15838ba504c93bcef623c937acddd.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pbh.yn.gov.cn/contents/58/4039.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ug.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t937360.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.moh.gov.cn/gjhzs/dyhbz/201308/38f15838ba504c93bcef623c937acddd.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: On November 2, 2010, China announced it would loan Uganda 100 million USD to be used to upgrade and maintain Uganda's road network. The concessional loan was repayable within 40 years with a 10-year grace period. Sometime around July 2012, Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni presided over the first batch of equipment purchased with the loan entering the country for the work on the Uganda's road network, including 159 graders, 257 tipper trucks, 12 wheel loaders, six dozers, seven excavators and two loaders. These machine form part of a total of 1,400 units to be procured with the loan. The current status and end date are unknown.

description: In 2009, Chinese investment company Hebei Hanhe send a medical team to Uganda to practice traditional physical therapy. The team educates the public on Chinese traditional medicine, cooperates with local hospitals and clinics, and organizes public benefit activities. Occasionally, the medical team offers free health check-ups and traditional medicine therapies.

description: On January 18, 2010, the Chinese government donated over 244,000 doses of anti-malarial drugs worth 400,000 USD to the Uganda. China's ambassador to Uganda, Sun Heping, handed over the donation of 144,000 doses of Arco and 100,000 doses of Duo-Cotexin to Richard Nduhuura, State Minister for General Duties in the Health Ministry.

description: In July 2010 in Kampala, work began on the refurbishment of the Chinese-built Mandela National Stadium, Namboole. The refurbishment was funded by a grant of 3 million USD from the Chinese government. The main athletics track was resealed and marked. Tartan was laid on the training track that was previously tarmacked. A new multi-purpose scoreboard was fitted. A better public address system was fixed; security lighting outside the stadium was also repaired. The stadium was handed over to the Ugandan government on April 17, 2011.

description: On January 13, 2009, Ugandan Minister of Foreign Affairs Sam Kutesa and Chinese Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi signed an agreement for a (concessional?) loan for the construction of a country-wide e-governance project. The project was delayed in January, 2010 after the completion of Phase I of the 3-stage project when the project was projected to cost substantially more than the initial 60 million USD and following allegations of fraud and mismanagement by the project implementer, Huawei Technologies. After establishing the National Information Technology Authority Uganda (NITA-U) to oversee the implementation of Phases II and III, the project was continued with a cost of 106,590,305 USD, which was co-financed by the Ugandan government and concessional loans from the China Exim Bank to be repaid within 20 years. By February 7, 2011, Phases I and II of the project had been completed and operationalized, and Phase III was slated to begin work soon. The first two phases cost 91 million USD with 30 million USD spent on Phase 1 and 61 million USD spent on Phase 2. The last phase would begin once EXIM Bank released the final funds.

description: China has been sending medical teams to Uganda since 1983. Yunnan Province has been responsible for sending the teams. On August 2009, the 14th medical team of 8 members arrived at the Jinja Hospital in Uganda. The team trained local medical personnel and sent 8 doctors from Jinja Hospital for training in China. They completed their mission in August 2011.

description: In 2009, as a result of the 2009 FOCAC forum, China and Uganda joined forces to build an aquaculture technology demonstration center at Kajjansi Aquaculture Research and Development Centre in Kampala. When the originally designated funding from the Government of Uganda fell short, the Chinese government issued a grant so that the center could be realized. The project was implemented by Sichuan Huaqiao Fenghuang group and funded by the Chinese government. The project was completed in December 2010.

The school, estimated at a cost of 700,000 USD, was recently handed over to the school administration by the Chinese ambassador, Sun Heping, together with the security minister, Amama Mbabazi. The school is named 'China-Uganda Friendship School.' description: On June 30, 2009, the Chinese government donated medical equipment worth 300,000 USD to Uganda to boost its effort to promote reproductive health. Wang Zeshan, Charge d'affaires at the Chinese Embassy handed over the equipment to Uganda's Health Minister Stephen Malinga. The equipment included an ultra sound, a urine analysis equipment, an ECG machine, a mammogram machine, and some theatre lamps and tables. The donation will go to the Mulago and Jinja hospitals.

description: In 2009, Hebei Hanhe Investment Co., under the direction of Qiu Lijun, began trial planting and experimentation in Uganda. African Development Fund under the China Development Bank assisted in funding the Hanhe Uganda Hebei Farm. In 2011 the Hanhe Uganda Hebei farm started cultivating vegetables on a large scale, covering 2,600 mu (173 hectares) of land in Uganda, with plans of expanding to 260,000 mu (17,333 hectares) in the future. The farm had an initial capital of 9.9 million CNY and a reported total area of 20,000 acres in 2010, but it is unclear what portion of this 9.9 million CNY is from the CDB. The farm prepares the following products for export: cotton, coffee, leather, African handicraft clothing, marine products, rosewood, and ebony.

description: On May 15, 2008, the Ugandan Parliament approved a loan from the China Export Import Bank worth 10 million USD for road and sanitation equipment for Kampala City Council. The loan has a maturity period of 20 years and seven years of grace. The interest is two percent on the disbursed and outstanding loan. The grant element of the loan is approximately 41.96 percent. The equipment will be supplied by China First Automobile Works. The current status and end date are unknown.

description: On January 6, 2008, Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni and Zhang Aiming, the economic and commercial counselor at the Chinese Embassy in Uganda, agreed for China to construct an export promotions centre in Bugolobi, Uganda. Uganda also offered to provide land for the project. By 2010, China (through its Embassy in Uganda) had signed an agreement with Uganda's Ministry of Tourism, Trade, and Industry. By January 2011, Uganda Export Promotion Board reported it had secured land for the project and was in the process of securing the necessary Statutory consents such as Environmental Impact Assessments and approval of site plans. According to plans, the export promotions centre will contain the publicly-owned UGANDA EXPORT DEVELOPMENT AND THE EAST AFRICAN EXPORT SKILLS DEVELOPMENT CENTRE as well as the privately-owned REGIONAL RE-EXPORT TRADE HUB, housing 300 e-commerce centers with Uganda, China, East African Countries and other interested companies in the first phase. Other stakeholders include Uganda Broadcasting Corporation (UBC) and Ministry of East Africa Affairs. The amount, current status, and start and end dates are unknown. STAFF_NOTES: Since the proposed center will house Chinese companies and thus support private investment, the flow_class is OOF.
sources: http://www.aercafrica.org/documents/china-africa-country-cases/Uganda_Aid_Relations.pdf, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/605558, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.aaeafrica.org/start/mixed-outlook-for-the-ugandan-msme-sector/, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.ugandaexportsonline.com/2009/articles.php, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://ug.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200808/20080805703293.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Zhang Aiming, Economic and Commercial counselor ; Yoweri Museveni, President

description: On October 3, 2008, China's ambassador to Uganda, Sun Heping, announced that China would build a hospital and malaria treatment/prevention center called the China-Uganda Friendship Hospital in Naguru, Uganda with a grant of 6 million USD. The 5772.8-square-meter hospital was slated to begin construction in August 2009. The groundbreaking ceremony was held on September 23, 2009. Construction completed in November 2011. The handover ceremony was held on January 10, 2012. In June 2012, Jing Yanhui, an official from the Chinese embassy in Uganda, announced that a malaria treatment and prevention center would be added on to the hospital in the near future. The start date is unknown.

description: Following a visit to Uganda by Wen Jiabao in 2006, a donation was secured for the construction of an office block for the offices of the president and prime minister. On April 27, 2007, an agreement was signed between the Ugandan Deputy Secretary to the Treasury Keith Muhakanizi and representatives of Ms Yanjian Company for the construction of the office block at a cost of 25 million USD to the Chinese Government. The two towers of offices, located on Plot 9-11 on Sir Apollo Kaggwa Road in Kampala, finished construction in August 2010 and were handed over to Prime minister Amama Mbabazi in a ceremony on January 12, 2012. The final cost for the Chinese government was 27 million USD.

description: On October 29, 2007 in the Ministry of Education boardroom in Kampala, Uganda, Chinese Ambassador to Uganda Fan Guijin anounced a donation of 2 billion UGX for the construction of two model agricultural primary schools in rural areas. This followed a signing of an agreement on September 18, 2007. Building was going to begin once the government chose the needy areas for the schools. According to the Ugandan Aid Management Platform, the schools were constructed in Kanungu District and Sembabule District. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.

description: On November 21, 2007 at the Commonwealth Business Forum in Kampala, Uganda, Ugandan MFK Corporation and Chinese China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC) announced they would undertake a joint venture to construct a car assembly factory at Kato Aromatic Industrial Park in Mukono, Uganda. The first phase of the project of erecting equipment was underway with spending of 10 million USD. Initial project funding of $10 million USD came from the China-Africa Development Fund. Once fully constructed, the assembly line is expected to produce 3,000 vehicles per year and cost 300 million USD. The current status of the project is unknown as well as the end date.

description: The Chinese Government has been sending experts to the stadium from 1997 to look after the training of the local technicians, maintenance of the facilities, and providing technical supports. Up to now three teams and altogether 21 Chinese experts have been sent to Uganda at the Chinese Government's own expenses. The Chinese commitment for economic cooperation at Mandela stadium was 4,451,357 USD. However, by 2007 only 484,835 USD had been disbursed, with all disbursements from 2001-2003. The current status and end date are unknown.

description: In 2004, Uganda funded and began renovation on its State House in Entebbe. The Chinese had offered over 5 million USD for the project, and was also expected to extend a grant or low interest loan for the project. After deterioration, the building was demolished and a the construction of a new state house was commissioned on November 10, 2007, just in time for the Commonwealth Summit, with a final cost of $93 million USD. Reports indicated the project was at least partially funded by a grant from the Chinese government. One anonymous source said: ''The Chinese asked the government to tell them how much renovating State House would cost and what Uganda can afford. They also offered to finance the balance.' The construction was done by the 23rd Metallurgical Construction Corporation of Non-Ferrous Metal Industry of China with Project Manager Henry Kazahuura.

description: In 2002, China and Uganda signed an agreement for the construction of a building for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. According to Ugandan data, $4,742,436 USD were given out from the agreement. On November 28, 2002, China's Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister Yang Wenchang and Uganda's Minister for the Presidency and Acting Foreign Secretary Gilbert Bukenya signed an agreement for a grant worth 6.5 billion UGX to help with shortages in the construction of the foreign affairs ministry on Plot 2 Apollo Kaggwa Road, Kampala, Uganda. On the same day, the groundbreaking ceremony for the construction project took place, and China donated 217 million UGX for furniture for the building once completed. The building was projected to be completed within fourteen months. Chinese payments for the construction ended in 2003, and several sources cite the building as completed. The exact end date is unknown.

description: Project Description: EXIM Bank of China loans Uganda US$ 482.5m to contract China Water International Corporation to construct the Isimba hydropower project. The loan has a maturity of 20 years, including a five year grace period and a fixed interest rate of two per cent per annum. As of March 15, 2015, Parliament has approved the loan. Uganda Gets IMF OK to Raise Debt Limit; Move Aimed at Allowing East African Nation to Fund Needed Hydroelectric Projects Nicholas Bariyo Nicholas Bariyo 374 words 27 January 2014 06:00 AM The Wall Street Journal Online WSJO WSJ.com English Copyright 2014 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. KAMPALA, Uganda—The International Monetary Fund has cleared Uganda to increase its debt ceiling on non-concessional borrowing by up to 47%, to allow the East African nation to fund ambitious hydroelectric projects aimed at addressing chronic power shortages. The country's borrowing limit has been increased to $2.2 billion from $1.5 billion, a boost for the country's efforts to access funds to meet its widening budget deficit, Ana Lucia Coronel, the IMF's senior resident representative in Uganda, said Monday. The development is a relief for Africa's top robusta coffee grower and fledging oil producer; Uganda has been grappling with a widening budget deficit for the past two years, as spending has increased while funds from donors waned. 'The allowed increase is expected to finance electricity projects that are critical to close the acute infrastructure gap that makes Uganda one of the countries with the lowest levels of electrification in Africa,' Ms. Coronel said. Rating firm Standard & Poor's Corp. recently lowered Uganda's credit rating to B from B+, citing the widening deficit. The country's largest donors, including the European Union and the World Bank, froze aid in 2012, citing high levels of corruption in government. Until 2012, donors were funding around 30% of the country's annual budget. China's Sinohydro Group Ltd. is building the 600 megawatt Karuma hydro power plant on the River Nile, while China International Water and Electric Corp. is implementing the 183 megawatt Isimba hydro power projects, both located along the White Nile, a tributary of the Nile. The projects, being funded by concessional loans provided by Exim Bank of China, are expected to enable Uganda to meet rising local and regional electricity demand. Ms. Coronel said the IMF expects Uganda to get favorable borrowing terms in the continuing negotiations with the Chinese lenders. 'If well managed, the projects look commercially viable according to the information provided to the IMF,' she said. 'The terms of this financing will compare favorably to a potential issue of a bond in international markets and to issuance of domestic debt.' Dow Jones & Company, Inc. description: Project Description: China's Guangzhou Dongsong Energy Group invests over US$ 600m in a mining project for phosphate deposits at Sukulu in eastern Uganda. The funds will be used to construct phosphate fertilizer plant with a production capacity of at least 300,000 tonnes per annum. There will be a steel mill with a capacity of not less than 300,000 tonnes per year as well. A power plant of 12 megawatts will also be set up and a sulphuric acid plant, with a capacity of 400,000 tonnes per year, will also be established. A few days before Christmas 2014, the government signed an agreement with Guangzhou. Despite this signing, Guangzhou has found themselves in a legal dispute with Nilefos Minerals Limited over the ownership of the land. China to fund $620m Tororo mining project 368 words 18 July 2014 New Vision NEWVEN English © 2014 NEWVISION. All Rights Reserved. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com company By Vision Reporter Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi has said the Government is encouraging foreign direct investments after discovering several commercial quantities of mineral, oil and gas deposits to enable the country attain middle-income status within the next three years. 'We have induced an environment that is fully supportive of foreign direct investment, and we feel we are valued partners because Africa's voice is beginning to be heard internationally in the quest for development,' he said. The PM was meeting a delegation from the China-Africa Development Fund, the largest Chinese private equity that focuses on stimulating and facilitating Chinese investments in Africa, at his office this week. The fund will finance the proposed $620m mining project in Osukuru hills in Tororo district, undertaken by a Chinese company, Guangzhou Dongsong Energy Group, which is prospecting for base metals, phosphates and uranium on 26sqkm covering 14 villages. According to a release from the Prime Minister's Office, Mbabazi said Tororo has the second largest phosphate deposits in Africa, with exploitation estimated to last 35 years. Under the project, the company will produce 300,000 tonnes each of fertilisers and steel annually, establish a 200,000-tonne annual capacity sulfuric acid plant and also build a 5-MW power plant in the area. Mbabazi commended China for standing by Uganda, saying the country is an example to Africa in her revolutionary struggles against foreign domination. Lu Qingcheng, the vice-president of China-Africa Development Fund, who led the eightmember delegation, said the fund, which was founded in 2006 by former Chinese president Hu Jintao, is a channel for sustainable Sino-Africa cooperation. 'My visit has cemented my confidence in the project as one of the key investments towards Vision 2040 that will drive Chinese partnerships,' said Qingcheng, adding that he was impressed with the scale of the Tororo project. Guangzhou Dongsong Energy Group specialises in infrastructure development, manufacturing and agriculture value addition. Also related to this story China-Africa trade surpassed $200 billion in 2013 China an ideal partner for Uganda's economic development Chinese investments in Uganda now at sh1.5 trillion West envious of China's influence in Uganda COPYRIGHT New Vision Printing & Publishing Company Limited Document NEWVEN0020140718ea7i0005m UI Ver:80.1.0 Mod:17:07 ID:FWEB12 　 东送集团投资乌干达 建国家海外能源储备基地 http://www.gd.chinanews.com 2014年08月22日 16:38 来源:广东新闻网 　　广东新闻网广州8月22日电 (记者 索有为)记者22日获悉，乌干达共和国能源矿产部日前与广州东送能源集团(下称“东送能源”)共同举行仪式，宣布乌干达苏库卢磷酸岩综合产业开发项目正式开工。东送能源成为了广东首家民营能源企业涉足乌干达重点矿业领域投资。 　　乌干达总统穆塞韦尼在开工仪式上表示，该项目投产后，可年产30万吨化肥、30万吨钢筋、10万吨稀土及4万吨铌和钪等，同时还能提供12兆瓦的年发电量，每年可为乌干达带来6亿美元产值，而这个可连续生产100年的项目，也结束了乌干达没有化肥生产的历史。 　　苏库卢磷酸岩综合产业开发项目所产出的氧化钪，约占到全世界总产量的三分之一左右。钪铝合金为军用飞机、火箭航天工程所需的重要材料，目前这一产品及技术主要掌控在美国及俄罗斯手中。此次项目已被看作是中国重要的海外资源储备基地。 　　当日，广东省省长朱小丹为项目的开工发来贺信，贺信表示，该项目是广州东送能源集团在乌干达投资的重点工程，对于加强粤乌贸易往来、扩大互利合作，都具有积极的促进作用。 　　另据透露，早在2012年3月南非德班金砖会议上，乌中双方高层会晤时提出，将苏库卢磷酸岩多金属矿项目交给实力雄厚的中国企业开发。2013年5月13日乌干达能源矿产部确认将苏库卢磷酸岩多金属矿床交给广州东送能源集团有限责任公司开发。 　　东送集团表示，在项目建设过程中将十分注意与当地共享成果，该公司未来将把矿产资源在乌干达本地深加工，不断延长产业链，以促进当地经济发展、解决就业，为中国企业海外矿业开发树立良好形象。(完) (Republic of Uganda and Guangdong Dongsong Energy Group held a ceremony celebrate the start of a comprehensive phosphate development program. The program is expected to produce 300,000 tonnes of chemical fertilizer, 300,000 tonnes of steel, 200,000 tonnes of sulphuric acid, 300,000 tonnes of gypsum, 100,000 tonnes of rare-earth metal, and 40,000 tonnes of rare metals like niobium and scandium.) 中国民企投资乌干达国家发展计划重点矿业工程开工 2014-08-20 08:54:06 | 来源：国际在线专稿 | 编辑：朱苑桢 　　国际在线消息：18日，由中国民营企业广州东送能源集团投资的乌干达苏库卢磷酸岩综合产业开发项目举行开工仪式，乌干达总统穆塞维尼在为工程奠基时表示，这一项目是乌干达2040年远景规划的骨干项目，也是乌中两国经贸投资合作的重点工程。 　　在2013年3月南非德班金砖国家峰会外围会议上，中国国家主席习近平在与乌干达总统穆塞韦尼会晤期间达成共识，由两国共同开发位于乌干达东部托罗罗区的苏库卢磷酸岩多金属矿床项目。穆塞韦尼总统在当天的开工仪式上说，这项投资6.2亿美元的项目能让1200人直接就业，产量和产值都很可观：　 　　“这一项目可以年产30万吨化肥、30万吨钢筋、20万吨硫酸、30万吨石膏、10万吨稀土及4万吨铌和钪等稀有金属产品，年发电12兆瓦，每年能给乌干达带来6亿美元产值，并能连续生产100年。” 　　广州东送能源集团董事长吕伟东在开工仪式上宣读了中国广东省省长朱小丹为项目开工发来的贺信： 　　“苏库卢磷酸岩综合产业开发项目是东送能源集团在贵国投资的重点工程，旨在向乌干达农民提供质优价廉的农业化肥，对于满足归国农业化肥需求、推进现代农业发展、提高农民收入，对于加强粤乌贸易往来、扩大互利合作，都具有积极的促进作用。” 　　乌干达政府对苏库卢项目的开发高度重视，除穆塞维尼总统外，乌干达总理姆巴巴齐及外交部长、能源和矿产发展部长等多位政府高官也出席了当天的开工仪式。在工程前期准备阶段，姆巴巴齐总理曾专门致信中国总理李克强，希望中方企业支持项目的开发。他对某些西方舆论称中国在非洲、在乌干达进行矿产资源投资是掠夺资源的新殖民主义这一论调进行了驳斥，并强调了苏库卢磷酸岩综合产业开发项目在乌干达未来发展中的重要作用： 　　“我们不同意那种说法，我们欢迎中国朋友的到来。我们拥有丰富的矿产资源，欢迎来自世界各地的潜在投资者，现在中国扮演的就是这样的角色。乌干达是个农业国，这一项目将使我们的化肥价格更加合理，从而促进乌干达农产品的产量，这对于2040年远景规划目标的实现，改变国家的面貌相当相当重要。”

description: China's Sichuan provincial department of agriculture plans to invest up to US$ 300m on a 17,000-acre farm. In 2014, they committed 60 million usd on a 750 acre pilot cotton farm in Masaka District on land donated by the local district government. They plan on expanding this initial investment by 60 million usd per year for the next 4 years (5 years total for 300 million usd total). It is unclear whether the project has reached implementation and is unknown where further expansions will be located in Uganda.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=RTNW000020140827ea8r000a4&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://finance.ifeng.com/a/20140828/13016328_0.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Govt-gives-750-acres-of-land-to-Chinese-investors/-/688334/2429496/-/dgy5iw/-/index.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://blogs.wsj.com/frontiers/2014/08/27/chinas-sichuan-to-spend-300m-on-17000-acre-ugandan-farm/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fibre2fashion.com/news/textile-news/newsdetails.aspx?news_id=167419, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://af.reuters.com/article/ugandaNews/idAFL5N0QX28Y20140827?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0, Media Report, including Wikileaks

description: STAFF_NOTE: The agreement was signed in 2011 according to Chinese sources. Project Description: Uganda secured a US$ 350m loan from EXIM bank of China to construct the Kampala-Entebbe express highway. The contract was awarded to China Communication Construction Company. Work on the highway was commissioned in 2012 and is expected to be completed in 2016. Private company to manage Kampala- Entebbe expressway 649 words 19 June 2014 Financial Services Monitor Worldwide FINSMEN English © 2014 Global Data Point. All Rights Reserved. Provided by Syndigate.info, an Albawaba.com company Works state minister, Eng. John Byabagambi noted that the International Finance Corporation (IFC), the World Bank’s business arm, has been consulted to draft modalities under which the tolls at Busega, Abayita Ababiri and Kajjansii will be managed. 'We have engaged the IFC to look at how tolls on the Kampala- Entebbe expressway will be managed by a private operator,' he said. 'We will also involve IFC on the Kampala- Jinja expressway, another toll road whose construction will begin once we procure a contractor.' Construction of the 51.4km road commissioned by President Yoweri Museveni in November 2012 was contracted to China Communications Construction Company (CCCC). Expected to be completed by 2016, the highway is funded off a $476m concessional loan, with China’s EXIM bank contributing $350m while the government financed $126m as counterpart funding towards civil works as well as $100m in compensation of Project Affected Persons for acquisition of Right of Way (RoW). The road will have five major interchanges at Kibuye, Nateete, Busega, Mityana and Kajjansi to facilitate interconnections with roads at designated locations including the Busega interchange at the interface with the Kampala-Northern Bypass. Leading EXIM Bank President, Li Riogu, CCCC and the Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) officials on a tour of the expressway’s construction site in Busega recently, Byabagambi said tenders for the management of toll plazas would be advertised in 2015.'I am sure we will advertise tenders for a private operator to manage the tolls in 2015 so that by the time of commissioning of the road (in 2016), we will have the private operator in place,' he said. The government plans to repay the $350m plus the principle to EXIM Bank courtesy of returns from toll revenues over a 25-year period. No toll fee has yet been fixed. 'The road will be like the Bujagali hydro power project. Users will pay a high toll fee but once we are through, it will go down tremendously,' said Byabagambi. At completion, the Kampala- Entebbe expressway will be the first toll road of its kind operated on a fee for service basis, with restricted access for intruders animals and people through fencing to facilitate mobility especially for new alignment between Busega and Abayita Ababiri. 'All motorists will pay to use the road,' said Byabagambi. 'I think even bicycle owners will pay because it will be a high speed road fenced-off with exclusion zones so that no cow or pedestrian goes through on to the road. There will also be no hump on the road so if a vehicle is driving a 100km/ hr and knocks a pedestrian, he or she will obviously die!' Whilst 15kms of right of way have been acquired courtesy of compensation of property owners along the road stretch, David Luyimbazi, the Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) director of planning, noted that there were challenges in compensation of property owners. 'We have challenges of absentee landlords, mortgaged land and wrangles over the compensation prices, but we are in the process of addressing this problem (of compensation),' he said. Byabagambi revealed that some landlords challenged the government valuers estimation of their land and properties, adding that recently, the Solicitor General agreed that UNRA get way lease. 'If the property owners petition court and it (court) decides that we have to pay them more money, we shall do so, but works should continue because the constitution even allows us to use land belonging to individuals and only pay them later. We should have acquired half of right of way if not for delays in compensation,' he said. Li promised more bilateral cooperation between China and Uganda to improve Uganda’s infrastructure. 'We (Chinese) work seven days a week,' he said. 'You have to tell your people (support staff) to work hard just like CCCC to complete the project in time.' Global Data Point Ltd. Document FINSMEN020140619ea6j000is UI Ver:80.1.0 Mod:17:07 ID:FWEB6 © 2015 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved. Terms of UsePrivacy PolicyCookie Policy 中国向乌干达提供3.5亿美元贷款 援建收费公路 2011-03-31　　中国经济网　　　　 　　中国经济网北京3月31日讯(王红娟)路透社今天报道说，中国提供3.5亿美元贷款在乌干达援建的第一条收费公路将于今年7月正式破土动工，这是乌干达境内的第一条收费公路，也是该国第一条采取公私合营方式建设的公路。 　　这条公路全长54公里，连接乌干达首都坎帕拉(Kampala)和恩德培国际机场(EntebbeInternational Airport)。全部建设资金由中国进出口银行提供，计划用公路收费偿还。 　　路透社的报道中说，乌干达政府和中国进出口银行2010年11月签署了贷款协议，预计今年5月份该协议和建设计划将得到乌干达议会的批准。 　　乌干达国家公路管理局(Uganda National Roads Authority，UNRA)发言人DanielAlinange说：“相关准备工作已经进入到最后阶段，今年7月份将正式动工。”他说：“目前存在的这条公路已经无法正常运营，大量车流经常导致拥堵。” 　　根据协议，中国进出口银行有权自主安排建设工程的招投标事宜，并可以自主选择运营合作伙伴。建设贷款的归还期限是40年，将通过收取过路费偿还。 　　乌干达国家公路管理局的一位官员表示，这条公路将是该地区建设成本最高昂的一条公路，每公里投资高达640万美元。这位不愿意公开姓名的官员表示，建设项目得到议会的批准后可能会对设计稍做修改，最终建设费用将会略有下降。 (China offers 350m USD loan to Uganda for the construction of a highway between Kampala and EntebbeInternational Airport. The loan is to be paid within 40 years.) 驻乌干达大使孙和平出席坎帕拉-恩德培机场高速公路项目贷款协议签字仪式 （驻乌干达使馆供稿） 2011/05/20 　　2011年5月20日，中国驻乌干达大使孙和平受中国进出口银行委托，赴乌财政部签署乌干达坎帕拉-恩德培机场高速公路项目贷款协议。乌财政部长布姆巴代表乌方签字。使馆经商参赞邹小明等出席。 　　孙大使在致辞中回顾了近年来中非合作论坛框架下中乌各领域合作所取得的可喜进展，表示，该项目落实了中国总理温家宝和乌干达总统穆塞韦尼在中非合作论坛第四届部长级会议上所达成的共识，也是穆塞韦尼总统2011年5月12日再次宣誓就职后中乌经贸合作的最新篇章。孙大使说，中方长期致力于支持包括乌干达在内的非洲国家提升基础设施水平，从而为乌进行国家建设和提高人民生活水平奠定坚实基础。此高速公路项目为中乌信贷合作历史上规模最大的一笔，相信通过双方的共同努力，项目一定会成为中乌合作的新标志和新典范，中乌友好合作关系必将进一步深化、拓展。 　　布姆巴财长对中方长期以来对乌的大力支持和无私援助表示由衷感谢，表示中方将基础设施领域作为对乌合作重点恰好与乌政府提出的国家发展五年规划相契合。该项目建成后将有效缓解乌首都及周边地区的交通压力，从而纾解乌发展瓶颈，并带动经济和社会全面发展。希望乌中双方继续在道路建设和能源开发等领域加强密切合作，共同谱写中乌友谊新篇章。 (Chinese ambassador Sun Heping signed the Kampala-EntebbeInternational Airport loan agreement with the Ugandan Minister of Commerce.) 驻乌干达大使赵亚力陪同乌总理视察机场高速路项目并慰问中交集团员工 2014-01-14 　　马年春节来临之际，1月11日，赵亚力大使陪同乌总理姆巴巴奇视察坎帕拉-恩德培机场高速路施工现场，并向奋斗在项目一线的中交集团一公局员工致以节日的问候。 　　在烈日炎炎下,乌总理视察了工地,与中乌双方员工进行了友好交谈,并现场办公,就解决目前项目施工中遇到的问题作出了明确指示。乌总理一行还专门到项目部办公营地看望了中外方员工。在接见中乌双方员工时，乌总理姆巴巴奇首先用中文向大家祝贺新年并表示，感谢中国政府为乌提供优惠贷款，帮助乌改善基础设施，提高道路建设能力。感谢中交集团为提升乌交通环境付出的辛勤劳动，乌中双方将密切合作，保证该项目建设顺利进行。　　 　　赵大使表示，中国政府高度重视坎帕拉-恩德培机场高速路建设，该项目的建成必将带动乌旅游、房地产等相关产业的发展，为乌经济进一步发展打下基础。这条高速路是是中乌友谊之路，相信在两国政府部门支持下，中交集团一定能按时、高质量完成该项目。　　 　　该项目于2012年底动工，连接乌首都坎帕拉和恩德培国际机场，主线全长37.2公里，支线全长12.9公里。由乌干达政府利用中国进出口银行优惠买方信贷款修建，由中交集团设计施工。该项目合同金额4.76亿美元，其中1.26亿美元乌干达政府自筹，中国进出口银行优惠贷款3.5亿美元。 (Chinese ambassador Zhao Yali and the Prime Minister of Uganda inspected the construction site of Kampala-EntebbeInternational Airport Highway. The program was started in the end of 2012. The main road is 37.2 kilometers and feeder is 12.9 kilometer. The total cost is 476 million USD. The Ugandan government financed 126m USD and China Exim Bank contributed 350m USD loan. )

description: SUMMARY: On September 23rd, 2000, Chinese Vice-Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, Sun Zhenyu, and Venezuela Vice-Minister of Production and Trade Luisa Romero signed the Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement between the Chinese and Venezuela Governments, lasting 5 years from the signing date. The projects will involve agricultural development, training in agricultural technologies (presumably), provision of (agricultural) machinery, and more.

description: SUMMARY: During Chavez's trip to China in August 2006, several accords were signed in sectors such as petroleum, housing, communications, and technology. China will support Venezuela in the construction of railroads, the installation of a rail and wagon plant, and the standardization of the national fiber optic network. The ground breaking ceremony of the construction of railroad project in Vargas was broadcasted. The railroad project, which is contracted to be constructed by the Chinese, would be completed in 2012. The expected capacity was 9,900,000,000 tons of goods and 5,800,000 people per year. STAFF_NOTE: The financial details of this project are unclear.

description: El Fondo Pesado I or Heavy Fund I was signed in November of 2007 and ended in November of 2010 valued at a total of 6 billion USD. The first contribution to the fund was made in 2008, with China contributing 4 billion USD and Venezuela contributing 2 billion USD. The Bank of China (CDB) and FONDEN or the National Development Fund (administered through Bandes) managed this fund. This fund financed a myriad of projects such as rehabilitation of the dam “El Guapo”, construction of 72 “socialist factories”, national electric investment, petrochemical projects etc. Clarification regarding the joint fund: ' CDB’s loans to BANDES for the JIF are secured by fuel oil sales from PDVSA to China National United Oil Corporation (Chinaoil), a subsidiary of CNPC. The three-year supply contract that secures CDB’s first loan of $4 billion requires PDVSA to deliver 100,000 b/d of fuel oil to Chinaoil.161 In contrast, the three-year supply contract that secures CDB’s second loan of $4 billion stipulates that the volumes delivered to Chinaoil will fluctuate with the price oil from a minimum of 107,000 b/d when oil prices are above $60 per barrel to a maximum of 153,000 b/d when oil prices are below $42 per barrel.162 PDVSA’s fuel oil sales to Chinaoil will range from 207,000 b/d to 253,000 b/d during the period in which the two supply contracts overlap.' STAFF_NOTE: The China-Venezuela Joint Fund/Fondo Estrategico Pesado (See #35985, #37528, #37838, #38163, 38316, and #38380) is marked as a resource-backed or commodity-backed loan.

description: The second Fondo Pesado (China-Venezuela Joint Fund) was signed in February 2009 and ended in February 2012 and was also valued at a total of 6 billion USD with China Development Bank (CDB) contributing 4 billion USD and the National Development Fund (FONDEN) contributing 2 billion. In August of 2012, CDB requested the 4 billion USD loan to be paid back in 130,000 daily barrels of oil, subject to changes in the oil price. The status of the loan is unclear. The China-Venezuela Joint Fund/Fondo Estrategico Pesado has received multiple financial commitments from the Chinese Development Bank (See #35985, #37528, #37838, #38163, 38316, and #38380) in exchange for oil. This project is marked as a resource-backed or commodity-backed loan.

description: In February 2009, Hugo Chavez and Chinese Vice-president Xi Jinping signed an agreement for the creation of a joint venture company for home appliances. In May 4, 2012 Haier signed an agreement with Corporation of Intermediate Industries of Venezuela, SA (Corpivensa) for a joint venture. Haier has invested 143 million USD to install the factory complex. On September 20th, 2012, the company built a factory for electrical appliances in Valles del Tuy in the state of Miranda. As of 2014, the company has distributed more than 3 million home appliance machines benefiting 500 thousand families through the program “My Well Equiped House”. STAFF_NOTE: Because this project was supported, at least in part, by the China-Venezuela Joint Fund/Fondo Estrategico Pesado (See #35985, #37528, #37838, #38163, 38316, and #38380), this project is marked as a resource-backed or commodity-backed loan.

description: Summary: In March of 2011, Venezuela signed a contract with Chinese company XCMG to purchase 6,025 sets of equipment for 744.6 million USD. The equipment was to be used in the construction of housing units. Machinery first began being delivered on June 20, 2011, with the last delivery in September of that same year. It was suggested that the money for the purchase came from the China-Venezuela joint fund, but was not confirmed. At the same signing ceremony, a joint venture was set up with PDVSA and an unmentioned Chinese company to carry out the construction of the housing. (project #37915 ??)

description: STAFF_NOTE: Unclear if loan terms are the same across all three credit lines. SUMMARY: In order to accelerate the oil production in Venezuela, China Development Bank has agreed to provide $4 billion in loans to PDVSA. This new loan would have a maturity date of 8 years at a rate of LIBOR + 5 percent. Additionally, two smaller credit lines of $1.5 billion and $500 million were provided for refinery operations and the purchase of oilfield equipment, respectively.

description: STAFF_NOTE: Unclear if actually aid, since other accounts report Venezuela as purchasing the equipment. May be partially funded by the most recent Joint-Financing Loan (#37838). _____________________ Summary: In September 2011, Venezuela and China signed an agreement for the China Communications Construction Company (CCCC) to dredge the Rio Orinoco canal to accommodate larger ships in the transport of iron ore. The agreement was for the project to cost 161 million USD. Reports stated that the work began in October 2011 and appears to have been completed in early 2013. Unclear as to the financing of the project.

description: Summary: The Chinese and Venezuelan governments signed a contract for the design, development and construction of a new satellite, the VRSS-1 (Venezuelan Remote Sensing Satellite) on May 26, 2011. The contract was worth 144.8 million USD deal – broken down into 67.8 million USD for the satellite purchase, 22 million USD for the launch service, 3 million USD for the first orbital operations, 16 million USD for the satellite control system in Venezuela, 22 million USD for the software, 2 million USD for the simulation system and 7 million USD for technician training. VRSS-1 (Francisco de Miranda) was successfully launched into orbit on September 29, 2012. _______________ 中国成功发射委内瑞拉遥感卫星一号 2012年09月29日 15:06:49 来源： 新华网 　　新华网酒泉９月２９日电（记者 李清华）２９日１２时１２分，中国为委内瑞拉发射的遥感卫星一号（ＶＲＳＳ－１）在酒泉卫星发射中心升空。这是中国首次向国际用户提供遥感卫星整星出口和在轨交付服务。 　　委内瑞拉遥感卫星一号，采用中国航天科技集团公司所属中国空间技术研究院航天东方红卫星有限公司研制的ＣＡＳＴ２０００卫星平台，共装载４台全色、多光谱和宽幅相机。这是委内瑞拉拥有的第一颗遥感卫星，主要用于委内瑞拉国土资源普查、环境保护、灾害检测和管理、农作物估产和城市规划等。 　　用于这次发射的长征二号丁运载火箭，由中国航天科技集团公司所属上海航天技术研究院研制。这是这型火箭的第１７次发射和首次投入国际商业卫星发射服务，也是长征系列运载火箭的第１６８次发射。 　　委内瑞拉遥感卫星一号是中国长城工业集团有限公司与委内瑞拉签署的第二个在轨交付卫星合同，也是中委双方继２００８年在西昌卫星发射中心成功发射委内瑞拉通信卫星一号之后的再度合作。 (The remote sensing satellite VRSS-1 that China built for Venezuela was launched in Jiuquan Satellite Center.)

description: In 2011 Corpolec began the first phase of upgrades to the Juan Bautista Arismendi thermoelectric power plant in Nueva Esparta state. This first phases consists of the installation of two 85MW generation units. The first unit went online by the end of 2012, with the second coming online sometime in 2013. The overall cost of the project was estimated to be 408 million USD, with funding coming from the joint China/Venezuela fund and Corpolec. STAFF_NOTE: Partially funded by the joint fund, but the amount is unknown.

description: STAFF_NOTE: Linked to #37838, #37330, and #35895. This fund replenishes Tranche B of the China-Venezuela Joint Fund, of which there are three tranches. ___________________________________________________________ Summary: August 2012-Venezuela is set to receive a new $4 billion loan from China sometime this month as the countries replenish a joint development fund that finances infrastructure projects and social programs in the South American nation. Venezuela is also obligated to contribute $2 billion to the fund, which is gathered from the central bank's international reserves and oil revenue. This is the third injection into the countries' bilateral fund.

description: STAFF_NOTE: Funded by #37838, the China Venezuela Joint Fund. Bauxilum also received large sums from the China Venezuela fund in 2009 and 2014. Uncertain if payments from the China Venezuela fund should be counted as separate transactions. Summary: In 2012, Venezuelan state alumina and bauxite company Bauxilum invested US$15mn to purchase equipment that will help normalize operations, improve bauxite management and extend the lifespan of stacking equipment. Some 50% of the resources to carry out the project were provided by the China-Venezuela fund. The status of these investments is unclear.

description: In Mary 2014, president Nicolás Maduro opened a new milk processing plant in Valles del Tuy, near Caracas. The 52 million USD project was financed by China. It is unclear exactly who financed the project, and who was involved with building, and whether or not China is involved in the operation of the plant. The status of the plant is unclear.

description: SUMMARY: Venezuela imported surgical equipment worth $127 million dollars from China. This deal, headed by the Health Minister, was funded by the binational fund between the two countries. STAFF_NOTE: The article implies that the purchase of the equipment came from the Joint Fund. Could find no additional resources directly referencing this sale. Is the sale of medical equipment assistance, or a commercial transaction?
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020140618ea6i000ul&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://sefar.gob.ve/?page_id=715, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.hrw.org/news/2015/04/29/venezuela-s-health-care-crisis, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.yiyongqixie.com/news/3/xinwen_11114.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

description: Summary: In October 2014, it was announced that China had relaxed the repayment terms for the oil-backed loans to the China/Venezuela fund. It removed the minimum quantity of oil sent for repayment (previously 330 thousand barrels per day), allowed Venezuela’s government to make contributions in local currency rather than US dollars, and altered the maturity of one of three loan tranches. STAFF_NOTE: It is unclear how the timeline of these rescheduled payments have changed. The specific loans in question are also unclear.

description: Summary: On April 16, 2001, China signed a deal with Venezuela for a 20 million USD line of credit for the Venezuelan government to use in projects revamping the agricultural sector. On May 10, 2001, Venezuela received 510 tractors and other equipment as part of that deal. There was no mention of any specific terms for the line of credit.

description: Summary: On November 1, 2005, the Venezuelan Ministry of Science and Technology and China Great Wall Industry Corp. (CGWIC) signed a contract for the in-orbit delivery of Venezuela Communications Satellite (VeneSat-1). The total investment for this project was $406 million. China was responsible for the design, manufacture, integration, test, and launch of the satellite. On October 30, 2008, a LM-3B launch vehicle successfully launched VeneSat-1 from Xichang Satellite Launch Center. STAFF_NOTE: The financing and flow type of this project is unclear.

description: SUMMARY: Financed by a $20 billion credit line from the same year, the tranche will pay for four thermometric power plants. The linked projects are below and are in various stages. The projects, to be developed in the 2010-2012 period, include the 550 MW El Vigia thermoelectric power plant (TPP) in Merida state, a new 600 MW unit of the Centro TPP, the 1,000 MW El Chorrin hydroelectric plant in southeastern Venezuela and a 600 MW coke-fired TPP in the Orinoco Oil Belt. STAFF_NOTE: Received funding from the $20 billion credit facility (#37804); likely supported by the first tranche of payments (#37821). These facilities are detailed in projects #37807, #38075 and #37538

description: Summary: The Venezuelan Government will promote nine socialist projects of agricultural development in the Guarico, Apure, Delta Amacuro, Barinas and Portuguesa regions, all aimed at strengthening agricultural plant and livestock production in the country. These projects are all financed through the 20 billion USD credit line from China that was established in 2010. All these projects will be implemented by the Ministry of Popular Power for Agriculture and Lands. The first project targets the Socialist Agrarian Project Guarico River, which is underway since 2009, and plans planting 35,000 hectares to produce 420,000 tons of grain from rice and corn, as well as rehabilitation of canals and construction of new The recovery of viabilities of irrigation and recovery of buildings for the benefit of the community. The second is the Integral Socialist Agrarian Development Project Píritu-Becerra, which is due in October, and includes the drilling of 100 wells, the recovery of agricultural viability, building a bridge over the Rio Guarico, lifting a communal city, the acquisition of buffaloes bellies livestock dual purpose, the construction of processing plants soybeans and pulse crops of rice, soy, legumes and vegetables. A third project will be implemented in the area of ​​influence of Biruaca-Achaguas Axis, in Apure state, and includes the construction of 167 kilometers of viability and improvement of another 55 kilometers in the region, and the construction of two bridges, between Apurito-San Antonio and Hato El Frio-Santa Catalina, the conveyance of water for corn, bean, beans, papaya and others, and encourage the production of milk and beef. A fourth project, launched in 2009, is aimed at implementing the second stage of socialist agricultural development in Tiznados by which it seeks to promote the construction of canals, storage silos for food from cattle, building a milk processing plant. The fifth project aimed at the development of the Orinoco Delta, which was launched in January this year, aims to strengthen food production through incentives for planting rice and construction of an agroindustrial plant for processing, plus rectification work of canals and rehabilitation of agricultural viability. The statement also refers to Agrosocialista Project Santo Domingo, also started last January and aims to consolidate agricultural production plant in Barinas state through the construction of irrigation canals and the socio-round development. The seventh project is related to the Agroecológico Llano Alto, in Barinas, and aims to promote the cultivation of cocoa, coffee and forestry plantations, the development of a community plan dual purpose cattle breeding under agroecological management and development of integrated farming, for the rearing of laying hens, broilers, sheep, pigs and vegetables. Likewise, the Agroecológico project includes the installation Llano Alto Boconó reservoir in floating cages for the production of pacu, establishing apiaries, the creation of a network of beekeepers, installing tanks in Australian Academy of Agricultural Sciences for growing fish under water recirculation techniques recycled and eco-tourism development. Project Agrosocialista Guanarito, Portuguesa, is the eighth of the plans to be financed with resources from China, and to strengthen social support infrastructure and production in that region. The ninth project aims to consolidate agricultural production plant and livestock production in the Socialist Alto Apure Axis, between Elorza-Mantecal region. STAFF_NOTE: Linked to the $20 billion credit line, #37804.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=SABIUL0020100830e68p00002&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mefbp.gob.ve/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=306:proyectos-desarrollo-agrario&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=401, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.alopresidente.gob.ve/info/6/1920/proyecto_agrario_socialista.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

donor_agency: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency
location_details: Guarico; Apure; Delta Amacuro; Barinas; Portuguesa

description: STAFF_NOTE: LIBOR was calculated by finding the six month average for 2011, which was approximately 0.0507%. SUMMARY: In order to accelerate the oil production in Venezuela, China Development Bank has agreed to provide $4 billion in loans to PDVSA. This new loan would have a maturity date of 8 years at a rate of LIBOR + 5 percent. The loan was intended to increase the rate of production from 330,000 barrels a day from 120,000 by 2014. It is unclear if this rate was achieved. Additionally, two smaller credit lines of $1.5 billion and $500 million were provided for refinery operations and the purchase of oilfield equipment, respectively.

contacts: Rafael Ramirez, Venezuela Ministry of Energy ; Zhang Xiaoqiang, Minister (National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC))

description: In March of 2011, Venezuela's Alcasa signed a deal with China's Chinalco to update and upgrade their aluminum production. The amount contracted for the project was 403 million USD, provided by the China-Venezuela Joint Fund. By October of 2011, it was reported that there were several difficulties with Chinalco's proposed improvements, and there was some doubt as to whether or not the project could continue. A release on Chinalco's website in June of 2014 admitted that the project was slow to be implemented, but at that date had been 78% completed. Because this project was supported, at least in part, by the China-Venezuela Joint Fund/Fondo Estrategico Pesado (See #35985, #37528, #37838, #38163, 38316, and #38380), this project is marked as a resource-backed or commodity-backed loan.

description: On September 19, 2011 CITIC and the Venezualan Ministry of Housing signed a contract for the construction of 116 residential housing units. The total cost of the project is expected to be $400 million and will be financed by the $20 billion oil-backed loan offered by China Development Bank in 2010 (see project ID#37804). CITIC completed construction of the first set of housing units by October 2013 and can house roughly 13,000 people. The project also includes the construction of 10,000 housing units on a Venezuelan military base.

description: SUMMARY: In June 2012, China and Venezuela signed a contract to build a transmission line to connect the Tocoma and Uribante power plants. It includes the construction of eight substations and updates the electrical distribution system in the central-western region, covering Cojedes, Carabobo, Portuguesa, Yaracuy, Barinas, Mérida and Zulia states Táchira. It was also announced that month that a Chinese consortium was awarded the contract. The consortium is comprised of China CAMC Engineering Co, China Gezhouba Group, and China Electric Power Equipment and Technology Co. The contract is worth $1.315 billion. A January 2015 announcement on the CORPOLEC website appears as if the project is still under construction. STAFF_NOTE: This project was most likely funded by the joint-fund, #37838. Unclear how much the fund contributed, however.

description: SUMMARY On June 3rd, 2013, CNPC and PDVSA signed a 4.02 billion USD Financing agreement with China Development Bank. The money will be used for increasing the daily production of the joint-venture SINOVENSA from 140,000 barrels to 330,000 barrels. Sinovensa is a joint venture between CNPC and PDVSA. It is unclear if the daily production rate increased the expected amount.

description: A new communications satellite was authorized at the meeting between China and Venezuela in September of 2013. The meeting included 27 agreements in which the two countries committed additional financing of US$5bn to a joint fund for a range of projects, taking the total funds to US$40bn. The satellite, known as VRSS-2, was ordered in October of 2014 and will be in operation by 2017. It is being designed and built in China. STAFF_NOTE: Partially funded by the $5 bln credit line secured by Maduro in #38290.

description: In July of 2014, the president of Venezuela, Nicolas Maduro, signed a new credit line with China for 5 million USD. As part of the agreement, 200,000 additional barrels of oil per day from the Orinoco Belt will be sent to China. The money from this credit line will be used to fund fund housing, agriculture, transport, industry, roads, electricity, mining, health, science and technology. STAFF_NOTE: This should not be confused with Tranche C of the China-Venezuela Joint Fund, which was also committed around the same time (See #38316).

description: Summary: In 2004, China gave Venezuela a grant worth US$ 605,000 in an exchange of diplomatic notes signed by Foreign Minister Jesus Arnaldo Perez and Chinese Trade Vice Minister Liao Xiaoqi. STAFF_NOTE: unable to find any other media reports confirming the transaction. UPDATE: Not economic and technical cooperation
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=IPRSID0020040420e04k00005&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

description: SUMMARY: China will invest around $5 billion in energy projects in Venezuela by 2012 as part of a plan to boost Venezuela's oil output. This project was signed at the 2006 meeting between Chavez and Hu (See #35972). The agreement with China included investment in a joint venture to operate the Zumano fields in eastern Venezuela and investment by China's CNPC in the Junin 4 block of the Orinoco heavy crude belt. The investment deal will aid plans to increase oil production to 5.8 million b/d by 2012. STAFF_NOTE: It is unclear if the final value was $2 billion or $5 billion. The time period and destination for the disbursement of these investments are also unclear. .
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=FINP000020060825e28p0001w&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=TOILDA0020060905e28t0000m&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://business.sohu.com/20060829/n245052803.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks

description: On November 14, 2006, the government of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela and the Chinese province of Shandong signed around 12 cooperation agreements in areas including tourism, technology, and housing. Among the agreements is the accord to study the feasibility of developing an Academy of Agricultural Science in Barinas state. Both governments signed an agreement to install a telecommunication network and a cooperation deal to recycle paper. Another mutual deal is the manufacturing of buses aimed at improving national public transportation. Both governments also agreed on efforts to develop tourism, the construction of 10,000 houses nationwide, construction of new levels on national freeways, and the creation of companies to promote the manufacturing of farm machines. STAFF_NOTE: If more information is found, potential to break up projects. Value amount unclear because of quantity and scope of agreements. Closely related to, if not a duplicate, of project #35969 (house construction).
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=APSPW00020061115e2bf000jh&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.conapri.org/english/ArticleDetailIV.asp?articleid=260994&CategoryId2=14940, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy

description: SUMMARY: The China-Venezuela fund along with Fonden has provided Pequiven 1.39 billion USD for 13 projects in Venezuela. Among these projects are the Moron petrochemcials complex and an olefins plant in the Jose complex in Anzoátegui state; these two projects are apart of a group of projects in which the China-Venezuelan fund has contributed 300 million USD. The petrochemical complex will create a new line of production of Methanol with a capacity of 1.650 MTMA. Additionally, potential petrochemical project complex options include the Puerto de Nutrias and Navay to produce phosphate fertilizers. The status of these projects is unclear. STAFF_NOTE: This project includes only 2 out of the 13 projects
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=WBNA000020090428e54s002jt&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pequiven.com/index.php/poderes/electoral/35-contenido/petroquimicadevenezuela/252-fondochino, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

description: Summary: As part of 11 bilateral accords signed on December 22, 2009 between China and Venezuela, China Development bank and CVG mining signed a 1 billion USD credit line to support Venezuela’s mining projects. Possibly linked to ID#37537. The status of this credit line is unclear. STAFF_NOTE: Sources unclear about allocation of these funds to specific projects. ____________________ Venezuela y China firman nuevos acuerdos en materia petrolera y financiera 632 words 22 December 2009 07:53 PM Agencia EFE - Servicio Económico EFESE Spanish Copyright 2009 Agencia EFE. All Rights Reserved Caracas, 22 dic (EFECOM).- Venezuela y China firmaron hoy varios nuevos acuerdos de cooperación, entre ellos varios petroleros y financieros, como un contrato de venta de 500.000 barriles diarios de crudo venezolano al país asiático y una línea de crédito china por 1.000 millones de dólares para proyectos mineros venezolanos. Los documentos fueron suscritos durante la clausura de la VIII Comisión Mixta de Alto Nivel chino venezolano, instalada ayer, acto que fue encabezada por el presidente venezolano, Hugo Chávez, y el ministro de la Comisión Nacional de Reforma y Desarrollo de China, Zhang Ping. 'Son 29 acuerdos' los alcanzados durante la reunión, 'pero se firmaron sólo 15' durante el acto oficial por razones de tiempo, declaró Chávez durante su discurso, en el que alabó a China como 'una gran potencia, pero para el bien' porque 'ha demostrado que no hace falta agredir a los más débiles' para serlo. Entre los convenios alcanzados destacan los del área energética, como el 'contrato de suministro de 500.000 barriles diarios de crudo y productos por un año' firmado entre la estatal Petróleos de Venezuela SA (PDVSA) y Petro China. Según datos chinos, Venezuela es el cuarto país suministrador de petróleo de China y su quinto socio comercial en América Latina y el Caribe. A principios de este año PDVSA informó de que suministraba 331.000 barriles diarios de crudo a China y de que tenía planes de elevarlos hasta 'un millón de barriles/día en plazo de cuatro años'. Venezuela y China también firmaron un acuerdo marco para crear una empresa mixta de refino en el estado venezolano llanero de Guárico y un convenio para ejecutar un estudio de cuantificación y certificación de reservas petroleras en el Bloque Boyacá 3 de la Faja del Orinoco. La estatal petrolera china CNPC participa, junto con empresas de Argentina, Brasil, Chile, Ecuador, España, India e Irán, en el proceso internacional de certificación de las reservas de la rica Faja del Orinoco, calculadas en forma preliminar en 234.000 millones de barriles de crudos pesados y extrapesados. Esas reservas, sumadas a las ya confirmadas de 80.000 millones de barriles en otras zonas de Venezuela, sitúan al país como la mayor reserva petrolera del planeta, con 314.000 millones de barriles. Caracas y Pekín firmaron este martes un 'acuerdo marco para construir y administrar una empresa mixta de producción de hidrocarburos en el Bloque Junín 8' de la Faja del Orinoco, con 'el objeto de producir 200.000 barriles diarios de crudo extrapesado', según la información oficial. Además, suscribieron un 'memorando de entendimiento' para que empresas chinas presten 'servicios de perforación costa afuera en aguas profundas y ultra profundas' venezolanas. En materia eléctrica, Caracas y Pekín firmaron 'un acta compromiso para promover cooperación' y 'desarrollar y construir proyectos conjuntos hirdroeléctricos'. En el área financiera, la estatal Corporación Venezolana de Guayana (CVG) y el Banco Chino de Desarrollo firmaron un 'contrato para abrir una línea de crédito por 1.000 millones de dólares', para financiar los proyectos mineros en el sur venezolano. Durante la reunión de alto nivel también se concretaron un pacto en el área de 'acuicultura de peces' y otro para desarrollar 'la tercera etapa del proyecto de rehabilitación integral del sistema de riego río Guárico'. Igualmente, se acordó un 'convenio de cooperación para formación de funcionarios públicos en el área de Planificación' entre escuelas de los dos países. A lo largo de su discurso, Chávez destacó el reforzamiento de las relaciones bilaterales, especialmente desde su llegada al Gobierno venezolano hace una década. Por su parte, Zhang Ping habló de los 'mutuos resultados de la cooperación' bilateral, y resaltó 'la gran importancia' que el Gobierno chino otorga 'a las relaciones con Venezuela'. EFECOM
